description:
My favorite is the 雪菜肉丝汤米。(shredded pork with snow cabbage rice noodle). One time I even finished the whole thing in literally 10 min. If you order before 11:30am, you get to order from the Breakfast Special which means drink included!!! If you want to add anything for $1, I recommend adding an egg or a pan fried turnip cake.

If you don't add anything, it will cost only $7.25 including tip! The best!!!
author: Andrea T.

description: Love their set meals especially the one with the cream of corn soup. So good. Their curry beef over rice and Portuguese curry chicken over rice is so good. Love it all with the dessert also whether it be the mango pudding or the herbal jelly.
author: Wesley K.

description: This place is alright. Has all of your basic HK style cafe dishes. Came here for dinner and go their special baked pork chop over rice. Comes with soup and a drink for less than $10. Got corn soup mixed with something that made it strangely sour. Pork chop was not bad, the meat was a little more on the chewy side but gotta love the rice and the sauce. I think they're better known for their congee. Might get that next time I come.
author: Tatiana T.

description: The Service here is really bad. I've never been so angry at a service before in my life. I came here to eat and my family and I are regulars. We've been eating here for several years already. Recently they would always give us attitude when we order and they also purposely try to get us to leave. And this one day we came in, and we were raising our hand to order and you could see her go to another table in which they did not raise their hands. And then, I let that go and shewent back inside, that was fine too. She made eyecontact with me and then she purposely ignored us and went to the table behind us even though they didn't even had their hand raised to order either. By now, it was obvious that she was ignoring us on purpose. Then I waited again, and this time I purposely said "we're ready to order" and then she said WAIT with attitude. At that instant I left. I dont know what type of attitude that is give your customers , who is also a long time regular. Never coming here ever again.
author: N S.

description: This place is very good for breakfast and afternoon tea! Great food, but slow service. The food is filling and especially with the milk tea that is included for breakfast, it bloats your stomach with carbs so that you will not have enough room to eat lunch. This place is 4 stars because the service is ok, because it takes a while to make the food and the waitress works next door at the sushi place because no overtime here!
author: Kevin R.

description:
Love love love this place. T-28 has become a staple of mine whenever I need some comfort food around Taraval.

The selection of food is very diverse so there's something for everyone. The meal comes with soup at the beginning and dessert at the end which is a nice touch.

Service here is fine, I honestly prefer when the waiter/waitress leaves me to my food, but they're very responsive if you need something. 

Food comes out FAST and piping hot, and you get a ton of food for a great price.

If you're coming to T-28, I recommend the black pepper beef.
author: George K.

description: the service is very bad, waitress have unhappy and unfriendly face,when we asked for the small bowl she was without looking ,no eye contect ,and you didnt  know do they heard or not, you are hard working we are customer will see it ,tips will be more .
author: Sukhing M.

description:
The food here is cheap and meh. It reminds me a lot of a HK cafe. It's not special, although my bf raves about the fried milk dumplings, which were too coconutty for me, but may suite anyone else. I got a macaroni soup with spam which was salty but not that flavorful. My bf's fried rice was pretty good and I think his friend enjoyed his food?
The service sucks. Like we came in and half the tables were covered in dirty dishes, but only an older lady made any effort to clean them AT THE END of our meal. The lazy young waitress just kind of sat behind the cashier doing nothing. Also, the waitress is kind of out of it because she took one of our dessert orders and then came back to deliver it and asked what my bf wanted for dessert. Even after we ordered, she never came back with the dessert. Yeah, I think she's a dunce if anything
author: Jenn T.

description:
I first came here back in 2005 and stopped after cause I always thought the food was oily. I came on a Thursday night for dinner just recently. I'm super surprised the food here wasn't too bad after trying it out. Of course I wasn't really looking forward to it, but like I said: surprised! They take card now too! 

Their menu is easy to read and they have pictures that made the food look good. I ordered the baked black pepper beef with spaghetti. It's good and edible, I finished the whole thing since the portion isn't too big, yet I was hungry too hmm. They gave me a lot of beef, and I thought the beef was soft to chew and easy to eat! Sauce was mildly bland, although some parts while eating I could taste it. My friend ordered the baked fish with corn sauce and rice. Fish was soft and I thought this entree was so-so, wouldn't eat it again if I do come here again. Since I ordered from the specials, I get a drink and dessert too! For the drink I ordered iced red bean drink, NO too watered down and tasteless. For dessert I ordered pumpkin with sago and I must admit, this was pretty yums, though very little. 

Food came out fast and service was quick. The waitress did keep rushing us to order even when we just sat down for 5 minutes, whatevs. My only complaint is for baked items, the temperature is super hot when eating. I burned my mouth and tongue.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Cute family owned Chinese restaurant, easy to understand menu, friendly and helpful staff, good vegetarian option! Must visit!
author: Kailesh I.

description:
Your average Chinese comfort food place. Cheap food and large portions. 
Came here with family and the place was packed. When seated we were swamped with menus. There is a large selection of food selections and specials. When you get the lunch special it comes with a bowl of soup and a free drink. We ordered a variety of options: 4 fried rices, 1 beef stir fry noodles, 1 tomato pork chop rice, 1 pork stew, and 1 curry plate. The soup of the day was corn soup and everyone got diff drinks (soy milk, milk teas, coffee, tea, etc). Food was decent, nothing spectacular, and came with large portion sizes. What was disappointing was a take out box cost 25 cents as well as the bag. Service was slow when it was packed. This place is decent for lunch and comes with large portions.
author: Jeanette Q.

description:
The food menu is very weird, its based according to times and days...and if ure eating at the restaurant or not. For example, hi tea is 2.30-6pm and porridges are $4.75 if u eat at the restaurant, but if you take it to go, it's $6, they dont tell u that.

Other menu are also based on certain times and days so it makes ordering confusing cause I came at 5pm today and certain food such as the chef special is not avail until 6pm....but I would say they have a variety of food, including fried milk! Heh beat that!

I got the baked chicken portuguese with spaghetti special with soup of the day, drink and dessert. For $9.75 is not bad especially the portion is huge but i dont know why they charge me $10.

The dessert I got was mango pudding. Sounds appetizing but DO NOT ORDER IT! I repeat, dont order it! Bc it tastes so fake, like room fragrance and also floor cleaning supply. Yuck.

As for customer service, the lady who served me was nice, she had her long hair in a ponytail. Everytime I say thank u to her she say you're welcome. For a chinese restaurant, thats very rare right?

To go boxes cost 30cents each. Bring your own!

I came in on a Sunday at 5.30pm and the place was half empty (or half full). During the weekday it's pretty empty so I wont say there's a wait.

There's restroom and they accept credit card, except for discover. Lots of parking.
author: Inez J.

description:
Dishonest store owner/staff

My review is directing to a staff/owner name "Ah Yee."  She was our server and cashier.

We had a large group dining there 1 night and our total was overcharged because they claimed they "accidentally" charged an extra item.  None of us could read the bill as it was handwritten in chinese squeezed on a small paper and not itemized (good luck if you can't read chinese), we really couldn't check the math until we compared to their in-store and to-go menu prices (which they are different by the way).  I know they say they can change prices without notice but none of the prices seem to match ANY of their printed menus, it is my first time seeing that.  Plus they charge for boxes for your leftover and the box prices are set on the fly as well, they put signs on the wall for box charge, that also didn't match what they charged us, they said they can charge different prices on different type of boxes.  Moreover, they tax you on the boxes.  Other restaurants box leftovers and for takeout free of charge in bay area.

There are plenty of chinese style cafe options in SF, don't go here.  I don't like dishonest owner that nickle and dime you, and changes prices on the fly.  They need to update their menu frequently then.
author: Christine H.

description: This place pretty good.  I like there curry chicken wings . And the sizzling black pepper beef over rice . That must try.
author: sean c.

description: From one human to another, do not get the red bean milk drink. The milk is water and the red bean tastes like grass.
author: Chris Y.

description:
Normally I don't really want to write bad reviews because no one is perfect. However, this restaurant is the worse restaurant I have ever been. Utensils are not just dirty, but have germs. Noodles are still stick together. 
If you don't want to get any germs or get sick, stay away from this restaurant. 
Giving this restaurant one star is already way too much.
author: Bun -.

description: So far , this is the one I like the most , this one Hong Kong food style is much better than others!
author: Bing L.

description:
Came back after a couple months hiatus. Customer service has gotten worse - had to ask 3 times for 1 glass of water.

My friend ordered a Sunday lunch special - the Steak with Black Pepper Sauce with rice. The steak was RAW. Look at the picture. They didn't ask how well done he wanted it (which isn't the issue) but it should either be raw or well done, not a mixture of both. No idea how he was supposed to eat that. I wanted to shove it back at the chef and ask him what the hell that was and it wasn't even my lunch.

Lastly, I ordered the Rice Noodle Roll with Combination Sauce and it came after everything else - 3 steaks, a wonton noodle soup, and a spaghetti. Not sure what took them so long...
author: Athena C.

description: Brought some salted fish and fried rice. It came with a side of roach. Very disgusting. I had to spit back out all the rice I just ate. Never going back here again.
author: Henry L.

description:
Got the afternoon tea special--the beef noodles with a free drink for 5 bucks.

Overall the food quality was pretty good--the lemon tea was ok, as was the beef noodles. Pretty much the kind of food I would be able to cook myself. The prices was pretty cheap. The wait staff seems to be pretty bored though. The interior is ok--basic "canteen" style seats and decor, pretty much the "eat and out" type of restaurant.

Overall, a place to have a quick, cheap meal if you are having a busy day!
author: Henry L.

description: The food is pretty good especially the Unagi rice dish I ordered. It comes with soup and a small salad a dessert and a drink. The salad is pretty small and only has lettuce and 3 slices of cucumber with thousand island dressing. The Unagi rice is good. The Unagi is very fresh and the rice is soft. There is also one broccoli in the middle but I wish they would put more than one broccoli. The dessert is really good but the portion is small but hey this dish is only $7.25. The service is nice and efficient. I would definitely come back for more!
author: Carissa C.

description:
I finally found my spot for Hainan chicken rice, my holy grail of Asian foods. Outside of Singapore, I have never had such authentic-tasting, tender, not-overly-seasoned Hainan chicken. I am SO happy I have found a place that serves it with al dente ginger rice. The ginger-oil sauce adds so much life to the dish, I almost had to ask for more just so I could douse the rice with it.

Their Iced Coffee and Iced Hong Kong Milk Tea drinks were also on par with hawker carts in Southeast and East Asia. Not sure why there are so many poor reviews. This place is legit.
author: Fiona Y.

description:
T-28 is your average Hong Kong style cafe-- cheap comfort Chinese food and poor service. Mr. Dubs and I came in on a Sunday morning and we were surprised to find this little restaurant completely packed. We were seated promptly, but waited 20 minutes to order and another 20 minutes for the food to come out. 

When the food finally came out, it was actually pretty decent-- you can't really go wrong with ham & egg macaroni and  dumpling and rice rolls. 

Despite the long wait, I'd probably still come back to take advantage of their awesome breakfast deal. However, if you're planning to stop in for a quick meal, I'd think again!
author: Tiffany U.

description: Truly unpleasant place to eat.  The service is terrible, and the food is tasteless, very oily, and overcooked.   Waitress spends a lot of time chatting with her friends, and can't be bothered to take an order.   When she is isn't chatting with her friends, she tries to look busy at the cash register but is not really doing anything.  When the order finally arrives, it has almost a half inch of oil all over it.     I will not eat at this place again.
author: Yang Q.

description:
Price raised...boo.

It's now $4.75 for a breakfast entree and your choice of hot milk tea, hot coffee, or hot/cold soymilk. Different temperate drinks may add another $1 to your meal. It's also $1 more for the additional sides now like the rice noodle rolls or chinese donuts, looked like there were a few other options as well...but I didn't pay attention.

That said, even at $4.75, it's a steal. I love having the nice big bowl of porridge for breakfast. It was especially good today because I was feeling a little stuffed up from a cold. It's piping hot and definitely heats the cold out of you.

Total came out to $5.20 with no sides.

Cash only!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Dishonest.ordered the lunch special.was overcharged they did not even bring the soup.that was ok.it was only $2.then ipaid with a $20 and she came back with $3 for what should have been under $10 meal with tax.so check your prices and count your change
author: cc c.

description:
Too much oil in their food. My stomach doesn't sit well with that. 

the menu said crab roe fried rice but it is fish eggs. misleading and need to rewrite menu. the turnip cake is not pan fried enough. it was soaking in oil and I had to blot it with napkins to get some of the oil off. so gross. the curry fish ball noodle soup was okay. I didn't like the texture of the hor fun/rice noodle. the lemon tea was too sweet and was weak in taste. 

cash only place. I'm never coming here again. had stomach pain after eating here.
author: Jules L.

description: Cash only, but its good, cheap Macanese/Cantonese dishes. Good for lunch and afternoon tea, they have all the classic Hong Kong breakfast items, like the macaroni soup, french toast, etc. Good sized portions, not the highest quality but it;s still a good place to satisfy your cravings.
author: Larissa L.

description:
I used to come to this place every Friday because of the great portions and yummy flavor. 

Unfortunately, I will probably never come back again. 

The service is not bad. The waitress was attentive(kind of).

Here comes the food. I ordered their lunch special which was a seafood fried rice. It was disgusting. My rice was dry and spoiled tasting. There was no seafood and the eggs in the rice tasted like dry flakes of rubber. My rice grains were burnt and hurt my teeth from chewing. 

My boyfriend ordered the curry hot pot. Also, horrible. The curry flavor was way off. Almost like the taste of sour milk. The meat was very low quality. Like the leftovers of someone else's meal. Very disappointing. 

It's sad because I used to go here all the time.
author: Julia Q.

description: The food is not as good as it used to be. The porridge is one of the best in town but I would not order any dish that contains beef.
author: Greg K.

description:
I love it here! My go-to place for cheap, decent food. I ALWAYS get the iced lemon tea! 

Came on a Friday night, and instead of getting the usual "daily special", I got the chef's special for 3 people. It comes with soup and rice. I was surprised the soup didn't taste like MSG!! 

The food came in less than 10 minutes. Good thing, cause I was starving! I ordered two clay pots (fried tofu with bok choy and eggplant with salted fish) and the baked chicken steak. The food was sizzling hot the whole time. Even after 30 minutes?! What legit clay pots! 

Chefs special doesn't come with dessert :(! It's $1 extra.
author: Fanny H.

description:
After a week of illness - fever, shivering chills, coughing up blood, I needed a hot bowl of jook (rice porridge) to restore my body and soul.  This bowl came out piping hot with bits of beef and a raw egg which I stirred into the near boiling hot bowl of rice soup.   I keep telling myself that this broth was hot enough to kill anything bad and properly cook the raw egg.  Half way into the bowl I start to notice a black bit of beef that was different in shape and color than all the other bits of beef.  The egg was now cooked and the jook looked like egg drop soup.  But that dark bit of beef came up again and this time it had legs.
OMG
OMG
OMG
I nearly threw up
Like the raven from Poe
Never more .
author: Jeff W.

description:
Nothing great, but that's what makes this place one of a kind.

You have the train tracks right out front. Windows don't seem to do much, nor does the foundation, so hold onto that coffee mug before it vibrates off the table.

Food is good, cheap, and satisfying. No frills, just your basic hits like beef or fish with jook. Get a combo and do the milk tea. It's excellent.

Carry cash. You know the drill.

And while you probably won't be bringing a date here any time soon, it's perfect for those looking to hang with the locals - a perfectly functional, cheap, and traditional Chinese Sunday breakfast kind of place.
author: Anthony N.

description: Business trip. Breakfast for two about $24 with black coffee, would not accept credit card and would not give a receipt for me to get reimbursed. My breakfast had no flavor, my partner's was a little better. McDonald would be better for next trip and they take plastic.
author: Frank W.

description:
I loved this place. Loooved. This was my go-to cute little cafe. I knew I could count on T-28 for cheap, amazing food, huge portions and good service. But I came here a little while back and everything has gone downhill. 

I arrived on a Monday afternoon with two other people and it was relatively empty. Normally, this place is packed with a huge lunch crowd. What happened? 

We were seated quickly and the first thing I noticed was that they renovated. Okay, cool, that's fine. They now have a jumbo flat screen television and nicer tables. The waitress was attentive and gave us time. She didn't check in frequently but came quickly when we flagged her down to order. I got one of their lunch specials - spaghetti with pork chop, which comes with a drink, soup, and dessert. The others in my party got Hainan chicken rice and beef noodle soup. 

On an earlier visit, we had ordered a great, sautéed noodle dish. It was huge and flavorful and delicious. We asked the waitress what happened to it, and she informed us that they reduced the menu. We asked if they changed managers and she said no. I'm assuming the subsequent reduction is quality is because they changed chefs...

The food came relatively quickly. That's where I was concerned. My pork chop and spaghetti were a bake. Bakes take a long time. (If you've been to Man Kee cafe and VIP on Broadway in Chinatown, you know what I mean.) So I was surprised when it came out as quickly as it did. 

It wasn't bad; it had flavor, it came with lots of spaghetti and two large pieces of pork. But the pork was chewy and definitely overcooked. The soup it came with was bland. I also got a coffee milk tea which tasted like overly sweetened tea with honey and some dark coffee aftertaste. Not pleasant. You could choose between mango pudding or some rice dessert. We got the rice dessert (it came hot), which was good. Not too sweet and very comforting. 

The Hainan chicken was dry and underwhelming. The beef noodle soup was good; nicely cooked beef and flavorful broth. But the broth was definitely full of MSG. The noodles were chewy but not perfect - it would have been better with a flat or thicker type of noodle. 

Service was great, as per usual. But it can't make up for what's lacking in food. 

All in all, I most likely will only be back out of convenience. Personally, I think Smile House up the street is better than T-28. Farewell, no-longer-favorite cafe. I'll just make the trek to Chinatown to get my fill of baked spaghetti.
author: Nancy C.

description:
You can't really expect much of this Hong Kong style cafe that's pretty similar to any other. The service isn't particularly great, the food is subpar, and the only reason many people come is for the cheap prices and the breakfast/afternoon specials.

The food isn't very great in my opinion, as I always seem to have an upset stomach after eating here...The food is bland, everything is drenched with oil, and service is pretty slow. The only real positives are the low prices and the large portions.

If you're looking for a better HK style cafe with cheap and quick food, my suggestion would be to head over to ABC, Tak Kee Lee, or Lychee Cafe.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Love cheap Chinese eats! Owner is friendly. 
Staff is as you would expect from a Chinese restaurant: efficient.
Food comes quickly.
Happy hour menu available.
Get a milk tea to compliment your dish.
Comfort food.
Wish they were open later, I would be coming for late nite eats, much preferred over ABC.
author: Veranna N.

description: It is a very traditional Macau restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. There are various kinds of food, such as noodles, rice and sandwiches. I ordered spam& sausage macaroni soup and milk tea. They are delicious.
author: Nancy S.

description:
Similar to HK Bistro, T-28 features a unique menu of all kinds of cuisines that don't usually relate to Asian food.  I've always been a bit wary to try it, but after a quick look at the menu (which is enormous and spans three different menus), the price was right and the dishes looked pretty savory.

It took a while to finally choose, but we ordered the pork chops with cheese and cream sauce and vegetable clay pot.  Both dishes were pretty good though the cheesy pork chops were a bit unusual in an Asian restaurant, but balanced each other out.  The soup that it came with was soul warming but had a bit too many little bones.

Service here is really bad mostly because there's only one waitress serving the entire dining room.  Prices are great though it can be confusing to decide which menu to order off of.  In my opinion, I feel like there's way too many choices and I wish they'd simplify their menu a bit.  However, it's a good deal and I will probably be back.

Food: 7/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description:
After reading many negative reviews from many of my favorite yelpers, I was daring enough and wanted to check this place out for myself. 

Well, for a Hong Kong Café, this tiny cornered café is a bit run down and continuously busy, especially on the weekends. 

People were raving about the Black Pepper Chow Fun. And I ordered the typical ABC (American-Born-Chinese) dish for $6.95. The dish is not much of a difference from the ordinary Dried Beef Chow Fun from anywhere else. Just a ton of black pepper is sprinkled all over the pasta dish. The overkill of the amount of the black peppers killed the taste. Chow fun: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TU6xwYgB3g56rgqHWhYhFw?select=C-pOzwLd9fbQMguPVrXG1w

I also had a dish of Pot stickers for $5.00. The side dish wasn't too exciting nor all that either. Pot stickers: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TU6xwYgB3g56rgqHWhYhFw?select=oTb3XUBz6q8G9hnUbzQp1Q

As I was eating my meal, many of the Sunset crowd was giving me dirty looks too, which also felt uncomfortable causing me to somewhat lose my appetite. 

"I know I'm fine and divine!"

Many of the yelpers were right. Lesson learned!
author: Matt G.

description:
I am their old customer. After they have remodel their store, all the menus and the chef have been changed. 

Food is expensive and price is pricey and the foods come out do not meet your expectation. They need to cook very delicious food in order to maintain their old reputation.

My stomach hurts as well. They might use the ingredients that have not put in the refrigerator and put outside so long.
author: Ryan S.

description: A small cafe with HK style service (no smiles but quick and efficient). Great place to get your  粥粉麵 fix. Good value - $5.25 for lunch special that includes a drink (milk tea, soy milk). Food is decent too. I would come back again.
author: Tina S.

description:
4 stars for their breakfast specials. 

I've only been here for breakfast. This is a go to HK breakfast place for me. I love their porridges and pork with cabbage vermicelli noodle soup. All their breakfast combos come with coffee or HK milk tea. 

I generally prefer milk tea. You can add condensed milk for an extra $0.25

Breakfast combos are about $4 so two people can have a yummy and light breakfast for under $10. It's a steal.
author: Milly H.

description:
T28 is a Hong Kong style cafe but with a Macau twist. You can find some Macau specialties here such as the Pork Chop Bun and also several variations of Portuguese Spaghetti. While the food here won't blow you away (especially if you're comparing it to the ones you find at Macau), the prices at T28 will surely keep your finance grounded. 

Within the vicinity of 10 bucks, you can get their special, which includes a soup, an entree, a cold drink (lemon tea!), and a dessert! Portions are generous. I usually take a small box of leftovers home. 

The non-stop Chinese pop music in the background can get a little annoying, but that's something I can live with. If you're within range of T-28, I'll strongly recommend this over ABC!
author: Ringo M.

description:
Really crappy customer service at this place. Negative stars for having to seat ourselves, grab our own menus, and ask for the waitress to remember to give us the dessert for our set menu. I would've understood if it was busy, but the place was half empty.

Couple the service with very bland, bland food. The words used to describe the taste of the sliced fish with cream corn dish was "rubber bands", the porridge wasn't any better. Go somewhere else.
author: Kevy C.

description: This place has really slipped off last couple years. A lot of the items that made this cafe unique from other Chinese cafes in the area are no longer on the menu.  This past saturday i came to try their  traditional hong kong breakfast... the price is good, but otherwise i was thoroughly disappointed.  I ordered siu mai chun fun, and every single siu mai came apart as soon as i tried to pick one up using my chopsticks, and the meat tastes nothing like siu mai.  The best thing about the plate is the sriacha sauce.  Long wait to get seated, long wait for the food, and my table remained sticky after the waitress casually wiped it... and i had nothing to stir my coffee with, so i used my fork.
author: gswfan ..

description:
Overall this is same as any other Hong Kong/Chinese cafe in the city. But the one thing they do well, is their fried rice. Every day of the week they have a different type of special fried rice that you can order. It comes with HK style milk tea and soup. I love fried rice and their unique fried rice just kept me going back for more. I probably wouldn't order anything else on the menu, just because I did it once and it didn't wow me at all. 

What I recommend:

-- Salmon and cod fried rice (which has masago in it also)
-- Beef sung fried rice with fried onions
author: Andrew W.

description:
I was craving some steak the other day, but apparently chicken steak is the closest thing to steak in the sunset!  I called in for a to-go order, and by the time I got here 10 minutes later it was already waiting for me.  

At first it was really good, but then it just got too saucy and too much... and $7 something for a chicken steak is an alright price, but I guess I just wasn't feeling it too much.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TU6xwYgB3g56rgqHWhYhFw?select=UIcMbnYoLotFc7v2PhE8ag
author: Liz W.

description:
I usually come here for a quick dinner or when I'm looking for a late night spot to hit 
up. The prices are decent, and service is pretty quick. Their prices have changed a little bit, but overall, the daily meals are an awesome deal. Soup, entree, dessert and drink for under $8. 

I suggest getting the chicken wings and the rice rolls. Their best deals are the happy hour items, though!
author: Steph W.

description:
Cheap food and delicious milk tea. Get their specials which come with soup, entree, milk tea, and a dessert. 

Open late.

Get the baked pork chops or baked seafood. My usuals.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Lunch special
Each day different comes with soup, drink and dessert. Most of the time I would order to go so it doesn't come with dessert but the food is still good.
author: Simon L.

description:
A convenient place for a hot bowl of rice porridge.  They've got specials between 8 am - 11 am for $3.75.  Add another $0.75 for a side item such as a Chinese donut or pan fried turnip cake which can be shared.  I like the hot steamed rice roll which comes with a mixture of hoisin and soy sauce.

Service is very slow and you always have to flag them down for your check.

Note: cash only.
author: Shirley N.

description:
4.5 Stars

+ Excellent Service
+ Good Food
+ Inexpensive
+ Clean
+ Extensive Menu

- Cash Only

My little sister and I came here for a quick bite to eat before going Karaoke last week. She has been telling me all these great things about this place (especially their fried pig intestines, and fried milk) so that was the main reason we visited T-28 that night.

We arrived around 8pm. The owner of the café quickly greeted us and sat us down in the center of the cafe. Upon serving us tea, he also gave us 2 bowls of "woon jai chee" (imitation shark fin soup) on the house. Very nice of him! (Really pays off to have such a cute and pretty lil sis wahaha X3) We also ordered the Fried Pig Intestines, Fried Milk and a Cherng Fun.

I've never been much of a fan of "imitation shark fin" soup http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TU6xwYgB3g56rgqHWhYhFw?select=VBENRIts1cMrdodl1F0XRQ because most places makes them hella watered down. T-28 is different. Theirs is actually thick and flavorful and you can see the chunks of meat in them too!

The Pig Intestines http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TU6xwYgB3g56rgqHWhYhFw?select=iLdkHn7-ZEvladof0A4NSg comes with a side of pineapples, onions, and dipping sauce. The intestines are dyed red so it kinda reminded me of BBQ Pork. It's good but a bit heavy for 2 people to share.

The Fried Milk http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TU6xwYgB3g56rgqHWhYhFw?select=TdaGEf_PjNuNiFA85j2BCw was without a doubt the interesting one. I was very skeptical about trying it at first but lil sis says it doesn't taste anything like milk. Being lactose intolerant I try to steer away from anything with milk in it as I can. To my surprise, she was right. The Fried Milk doesn't have any bit of milk taste in it whatsoever. 

The Cherng Fun http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TU6xwYgB3g56rgqHWhYhFw?select=0Oo2-qE9NE9mbR7_IJDI5w was also very good. Comes with extra hot sauce, peanut butter, oyster sauce and sesame oil. My favorite dish of the night, and also the most filling one.

Overall, everything I've tried there was very good and I wouldn't mind coming back again.
author: Mona C.

description:
I came here a week ago with my bf, we had an appointment close by after work and decided to come here for dinner. He picked the place.....

First off, we sat down and the lady gave us a STACK of menus. I mean literally there was like 4 different menus... kinda overwhelming for a small cafe like restaurant. If you came here with no type of dish in mind... you will be screwed and starving because you have no idea which menu to look at and what to choose from.

I ended up picking the 3 items for $19.95 which comes with soup and rice. I find this deal much better than their daily specials, just that the daily specials come with a drink.

What we ended up ordering:

Baked pork chops in tomato sauce: I was actually disappointed in this dish. I expected it to be baked, just like those individual baked dishes where the plate is piping hot and there is a baked crust on top. This dish was not the case. If you want a baked item, I would get the individual dish with the rice/noodles underneath it. There was no crispness to the pork and it wasn't actual pork chops, it was just cut up pork slices with white onions and tomato sauce. No bones, no crispiness, no crusty top from baking... oh so sad.

Black pepper steak: This was good with rice, if you eat this by itself you would think it is way to salty. Also, they are not kidding when they said black pepper steak. There was TONS of black pepper, and I am not saying it as a bad thing... just be prepared if you order this dish and you're not used to that much pepper. BF says this dish is awesome if you stir fry udon noodles with the black pepper steak... I must try that one day.. just not sure if this place does it.

Vermicelli with mixed veggies: a bit on the salty and bland side. I mean it literally is vermicelli with mixed veggies in a clear sauce (which could just be salt, water, and corn starch). 

All three dishes, the portions were HUGE! I still had left overs for lunch AND dinner! Just too bad the dishes didn't taste all that good. Service was so-so. We got one cup of tea 10 mins into sitting down... and didn't get a second one till our food came out... uhh did she just noticed there was two people?
author: Erica T.

description:
T-28, Corner of Taraval and 28th..  Open til all hours of the night, great for that late night craving you have.  They have great deals!  I have only been here 2 times.

This was my first foray into Macau cuisine of any kind.  My niece took me here for some rice porridge and some "Porky bun."  Priced right for the students or budget minded.  Porky bun is a pork chop in a bun!  And it's a type of traditional Macau food.  They have others.  I did notice rather interesting travel posters plastered in the dining room.  It had some nice half curtains in the window.

On my second try, it was the porky bun again!  I guess, I will have to try something new the next time, I am able to get up there!

If you have a some time, take a chance on T-28, instant classic Asian Diner...
author: Clayton J.

description:
I saw a group of 4 come in here for their prom dinner, how cute =]

The first time I came, it was way back when it first opened...or around that time and that was my first/last time here until today that is.

Daily Specials are such a good deal here for only $7.64, & the PORTIONS ARE GINORMOUS. 4 choices of entrees to choose each day.

7 of us came in at 6PM on a Saturday for dinner after a long day exercising & playing at the park, we were all starving. Good thing we came in around 6, because by 630 it started to get crowded.

I'm not sure what other people ordered...noodles, but I had the Saturday Pork Chop with tomato sauce special with spaghetti. For less than $8 it came with A LOT of stuff...a drink (choice of soybean, tea, coffee...), I had soy bean milk. It came with the daily soup, which was cream of chicken & it had bits of corn. Finally dessert, either mango pudding or sesame dessert (gee ma wu), I had the sesame dessert which was a lot bigger than I imagined. It was good but I actually prefer the kind I can buy in packets from Sunset Super, those are sweeter. I had some of someone else's mango pudding, it was a lot smaller but nonetheless still good.

For a total of $50+tip, we all left really full. I would definitely come back for another daily special and next time it wont take years.
author: Kylie L.

description:
I love coming here early on Sunday morning for breakfast. Up until 11am, they serve rice porridge, noodle soups, macaroni soup, and other kinds of Hong Kong style cafe breakfast (even though they are really a Macanese establishment) for $3.75. You have the option of adding Chinese donut, rice noodles with peanut and hoisin sauce, or white radish cake for about an extra $1 while hot/cold drinks are an extra 50 cents! 

My favorite is the salted pork bone porridge. So flavorful you don't even need to add extra white pepper. And their milk tea is super strong!
author: Liana L.

description: Cheap, Hong Kong style plates. Service is okay. Food is okay. It's a good place for a quick meal.
author: Mark L.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place and the day i finally try it was because the wait was too long at kingdom of dumpling

I regret coming here now because
1. Won ton rice noodle soup was SO BLAND. soup was super, super hot and didn't taste right. the soup was not flavorful and bland as hell. the rice noodles were not the good type. Ive had superb rice noodles and these were not good. wontons were good tho

2. rice noodles with peanut sauce, sirarcha, hoi sin sauce was ok. It was really watery around the plate and i've never seen that before

3. portugeuese noodle soup - nice flavors but there is no meat at all in it. the sauce got boring really quick and i didnt want to eat anymore of it. 


The service was holding it up atleast. The food we ordered was terrible
author: Kenny L.

description: Came here the other night and they even stayed open later for us cause we had several people and it took longer to decide, order and eat than usual. They have a weekday special that has a few dishes to choose from and a happy hour menu with several dishes for a good price. The portions are also on point with the price. I had an order of deep fried chicken wings which were good and came out piping hot and a bowl of pork and aged egg porridge (both on the happy hour menu - $4-$5) and both were tasty. I'd come back for their specials and happy hour menu again.
author: Tiff C.

description: Horrible horrible food. What happened?? I used to love this place The wonton noodles were cooked too long. We tried the bento box. Never had a bento box with spaghetti as a choice. But the meat was good. They should add at least some veggies. The drinks were tasteless. Shame on them, to put a quote on the wall.. saying:" If you don't visit first time, it's your lost!"  Really? Definitely will not return.
author: The Black Cat C.

description:
Best time to come here is early on in the day. Get one of the breakfast/lunch sets that will include some rice porridge, Chinese donut, fried noodles, and a milk tea or regular tea.

Porridge is piping hot, not too salty, or MSG-ey. Mix in the donut (which is pretty hot and still crunchy), noodles, etc and it will fill you up like the Michelin man. 

I've been here countless times during the lunch hour, partly because of the quite inexpensive sets, and also the spacious booths where I can grade papers. But more importantly the food does bring me back. And if you haven't already noticed, the name of the place is where it's located.
author: Ray C.

description: Cheap,tasty and fast. We ordered 8 dishes , shared it amongst us and  our bill was only 85 dollars.  I like their crispy noodles and fried rice.  The fried milk was good according to my friends but you have to have an acquired taste for it.  I personally did not care for it.
author: Claudine V.

description:
I'm going to have to up this place to 5-Stars!!

Great food!! Great prices!! And is very clean for a chinese restaurant!!

Their meals include a drink & dessert. Get the Milk Tea w/ Sweet Milk Syrup. 25cents extra...but it's worth it. Last time...it wasn't sweet enough after the sweet milk syrup was added. Next time, I would ask for it again, and if they charge me a 2nd time, I'll just pay 25ct less haha I'm such a cheapo.

I always get the Back Pork Chop over rice...but this time I got the Portuguese Style Baked Chicken Steak w/ Rice. Yum!!

Milk Tea w/ Sweet Milk Syrup
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/XLEU67j1tBh4fUWgmREbFw/l

Portuguese Style Baked Chicken Steak w/ Rice
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/lQW3QQI2AQUMuOUnFc8jzw/l

(Sunday, September 6, 2009)
author: Kenny C.

description: Breakfast is CHEAP! How else can you get a bowl of jook or noodles, a drink and a side dish for less than $5!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend last Saturday around 10:30pm.  Other than the two tables leaving, the place was empty so it was kind of weird having the whole place to ourselves.  I was very happy to see that they had a happy hour menu with jook on it (my boss had recommended this place to me but she said that they stop serving jook after 11am).  Everything on the happy hour menu was $4.50 or less, which is awesome.  My boyfriend and I ended up sharing a sampan jook, soy sauce noodles and turnip cake.

I loved the consistency of the jook (very thin and smooth) but it boggled my mind that they called jook with a few pieces of fish cake, squid, and cha siu (BBQ pork) sampan style.  Sampan jook is supposed to be seafood jook.  However, it still tasted good.  I now have a new place to get jook if I can't get all the way to Chinatown for it ;)

The soy sauce noodles were pretty good...flavorful but not too oily.  The turnip cakes were loaded with big chunks of turnip and fried to a golden crisp on the outside.

Overall, pretty good homestyle comfort food = 3 stars.  However, the awesome prices earn it an extra 0.5 star = 3.5 stars overall.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Pros: cheap price with various choices for breakfast, lunch, afternoon snacks and dinner; quantity is large and some selected menus go with soup, milk tea(if you are not originally from Hong Kong or Macau, you might not used to their not-sweet-at-all milk tea) and dessert; you don't have to wait too long when you're starving.

Cons: parking; taste and food quality are of average, maybe a little below average, but to be fair, you get what you paid for.
author: J C.

description:
Just when I thought I couldn't go any lower....

Just when I thought I struck A$N AM GOLD at Tak Kee Lee on Noriega SF for within a $fiver (where you can't quite find value like this in the Peninsula)

T-28 Bakery & Cafe (in reality, short for Taraval at 28th Ave, but in Chinese reality, T-28's Chinese name is Siu Fei Jeung (Canto) Xiao Fei Hsiang (Mandarin) literally meaning Disney's DUMBO, aka Little Flying Elephant, no idea why they named this place as such) goes even LOWER. Nobu K thought this place had something to do with a new version of Terminator. So yeah, N-31, T-28, S-69, no name sushi, nothing makes sense. 

T-28 offers a mini combo Ho' Ko' style brekkie with a slightly wider range of choices than TKL at $3.75 including a drink!

Several varieties of congee or fish soup noodles (supposedly) for the Chinese side of the brekkie menu

and of course the typical fried eggs, bacon, sausage type western style breakfasts bladitty blah blah.

just a little bit more variety than Tak Kee Lee.

So I opted for the most unique and representative of Macau Cantonese...

and got the salted pork bone congee. It was actually small pieces of bone in pork rib, brined and preboiled (or pre-steamed).

For $0.25 more I could add either a fried dough stick (cruller) or steamed rice roll crepes (cheung fun).

The congee was on the watery side, but hell it's cheap can't complain. Had it been thicker and creamier, would've been great.

The steamed rice rolls/rollades/crepes weren't even from Hon's, but some other generic brand off the supermarket. They put very little effort into providing additional sauces (just hoi$in sauce....). I guess you really do get what you pay for (Tak Kee Lee gave me peanut sauce, soy sauce, splash of oil, and hoisin sauce).

And now drum roll please.....

the hot Hong Kong milk tea

I must say it was quite the disappointment. When T-28 first opened oh about 7 to 8 years ago, it was packed to the gills. The menu actually at the time listed this drink as pantyhose milk tea (using the original nomenclature of this drink). Of course they didn't use pantyhoses to strain the tea leave mixture, but some cheesecloth type thing that stained from the tea and water. Back then I remember this drink being real smooth doing down the pipes. 

Years later something was missing. I cannot put my finger on why. 

The iced version was worse...could hardly taste any tea, and it was mostly condensed and evaporated milk flavors, with a hint of sour. This leads me to believe that whoever was doing the tea brewing slacked off, and didn't allow the tea mixture to properly cool down, or the tea "pulling" process (where the brew needs to be poured between pitchers back and forth to ensure an even mixing of tea and hot water) was shortened and/or not done enough or done right.

Considering the competition in the outer Sunset, I'm surprised this place isn't any better. But the locals still eat it up, like that father and daughter, this guy who appeared to be a regular, and this young Japanese married couple. Cheapne$$ and value does not discriminate. 

But bottom line

- T-28 is becoming less and less Macau style Cantonese and more like a typical HK style cafe with a few snacks found in Macau, but nothing in the way of brekkie fare (other than this salted pork bone congee which was a bit of a flop, but cheap)

-Noriega seems to have it better for Ho' Ko' brekkie fare.
author: Ken K.

description:
What can I say about this place, except that it's pretty darn cheap whenever you decide to go.

Breakfast, about $5 gets you porridge, your choice of "side" (chinese doughnut, soy sauce noodle, pan fried turnip cake, etc.) and a drink. 

There is a long list for lunch and "tea time" deals as well that runs around $5.

And for dinner, they have specials like 3 entrees for $20 and other such things, comes with dessert too!

The food is pretty average and the service is whatever but for the price, I guess so!
author: Wilson T.

description:
Some of the stuff on their menu is good, and some are so-so. I have tried some of their baked meet with rice dishes and they are pretty good overall. They come at a cheap price and the portion is huge. Something that a bit different is their deep fried milk. I was skeptical in this dish and wondered how they would deep fry milk. It came out looking like an asian twinkie. It's crispy on the outside and milky in the inside. 

Something that disappointed me was their wonton soup. It is so easy to make yet the ones here contained a foul taste too it. 

I wouldnt mind coming back here for some of the dishes.
author: Benjamin C.

description: The quality of food isn't that great but man do you get the bang for your buck. I suggest coming here with a chinese friend because it helps a lot. I spent more time trying to decipher what it was they were offering especially their daily specials. I suggest getting anything with the portguese sauce because you can get the others anywhere else. You definitely get more than you pay for. I came in hungry and came out 2 lbs heavier and in a massive food coma.
author: Nam T.

description: I used to frequent this place for a weekend lunch with family because the food is cheap and a bit unique, but the service attitude from the waitresses were consistently horrible. I have not made it there for several months. I live nearby so I drive by almost daily basis and the place hardly has any customer nowadays for last few months. Other eateries nearby have weekend crowd but not this one. I am afraid to go there now. If anyone has any recent info why there are hardly any customers, please share.
author: William L.

description:
Food is cheap here, if u only want cheap food to get full, here is a good place! Their meal is only $8 including soup ($0.5 extra to sub with fin soup), main dish , and dessert! Food is okay with this price, what can you expect !!!!!

Even cheaper from 3 to 5pm and after 9pm.

DO NOT order ice milk tea here !!!!!! Taste no good !

I will still come back for cheap food!
author: Lam K.

description: I love T-28 bakery and cafe. I go with my mom all the time and we always order their baked house portuguese porkchop with rice. Although it takes a bit of patience for their baked saucey dishes, it's worth the wait. In addition, their weekday specials offers drinks, soup, and dessert with your entree.(Their corn chowder is really good) It's so cheap here too! I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Katherine L.

description:
Typically when I'm in the city, my sisters and I have breakfast at Noah's Bagels, but recently they found out that T-28 offers breakfast specials for $3.75 which includes a complimentary drink, so we went there this morning to enjoy some Hong Kong style breakfast. 

It was quite difficult to select something on the menu since there's 10+ breakfast specials to choose from. Ultimately I ordered the cilantro fish porridge and a coffee milk tea. We were able to get our food within 10 minutes of ordering and it was quite tasty and the portions were just right! The fish was seasoned perfectly and the porridge wasn't too thin, just the way I like it. The cilantro is only a topping so it wasn't bursting with aromatics but it was a nice touch. 

We were there around 9 and luckily we didn't have to wait. My sisters said it could get really packed, so I guess it varies. I wouldn't mind going back for good, cheap, filling breakfast again!
author: Diana C.

description:
Not bad since the last time I was here which was since they first open, The food is a bit more decent, and now they have daily specials with more choices then just locking you into just one meal which is good, plenty of options is always great, and now you get to subsitute your soup with fake shark fin then their daily special soup which was today for me was cream of corn. Not bad. Had the baked pork chop, took awhile but definitely creamy and tasty as well. 

Prepare to eat in and finish because they do charge a small fee for the take out box. Cash only
author: Linh D.

description:
Do you know where Macau is?  Neither did I until recently.  I heard about it and the tasty sounding food that they are supposed to have there.  You know, Portuguese mixed with Chinese, etc etc.  How can you go wrong with Chorizo sauteed in soy sauce and hoisin?  Maybe a little chile oil to make it pop?

Given that I've never had Macanese food before I have very little to compared it to.  That being said, I wasn't too impressed.  It was tasty, but nothing amazing.  The Pork Chop sandwich was fair.  The roll was super dry and really didn't add anything.  The chop itself wasn't too fatty, but it did have a huge bone in it, which made eating it a little cumbersome.  

The Spaghetti with tomato sauce and chorizo and shrimp didn't taste like anything exotic.  Kind of like tomato beef chow mein from any variety of Chinese restaurants on Irving, Taraval or Clement.    The traditional rice noodles with mixed sauce was also disappointing.  Kind of gummy and totally relying on the taste of the soy sauce, peanut sauce, and plum sauce carefully portioned around the plate, surrounding a healthy helping of the noodles.  

The service was great though so they get a solid yelp for that. And there were a lot of people there, so maybe I didn't order the right thing.
author: Adam E.

description:
Service: 3/5
Food: 3/5
Wait: 3.5/5
Price: $
Presentation of food: 3/5
Presentation of restaurant: 3.5/5
Overall: 3/5

I always order the Cream of corn Pork Chop with Spaghetti, sometimes Rice. Their Lemon ice tea is pretty damn good, but its waaay over priced. But they are starting to do this "Special Combos of the day" type thing, which comes with soup, main dish, and dessert + drink for like $12 i think? So thats not too shabby.
author: Eva H.

description:
This is another Hong Kong style food place, they're pretty cheap, especially during happy hours. I've gone here a couple times, I usually get like the Macaroni with spaghetti sauce, this time I went I changed it to noodles, which is still good! :) It's pretty cheap eats, nothing to complain about. The food came out FAST, like there weren't anyone to be served, but it was a full house!

Customer service is pretty good and they're clean!
author: Danny W.

description: The food was just ok at best. Ordered from their lunch special. This place used to be cheaper with better tasting food a few years ago. Now it's just meh. If you do come here, order from their lunch special, because the other dishes there just aren't worth it.
author: Lily L.

description:
Came here on a late afternoon for some food--it was quiet. There were only my family and another table seated. We ordered the afternoon tea special...sounded pretty decent for $4 to $5, you get food and drink (cold drink +$1)...typical and fair enough. 

The food was just okay. I had the macaroni soup with sausage and spam. It was loaded with what felt like never ending macaroni, but geez, it was oh so salty. My siblings got eggs and sausages; man, those were filled with grease. 

Anyways, the service was terrible!!! First they messed up our order. Second, we asked for hot water and it never came. Third, when I try to get the waitress' attention for the hot water and bill, she was busy talking to the back staffs. Fourth, when we asked for the bill, they charged us more than what we had....continue on...

When we got the bill, it was over-charged. We studied it before we asked her to come over and found that she charged us for the wrong order she gave us and that was more expensive than what we had ordered. We told her the bill was incorrect and was more expensive than what we ordered, and instead of looking at the bill first, the waitress just said because we had cold drinks. And then when my mom was trying to explain to her we actually only got 3 cold drinks and 1 hot drinks. The RUDE waitress grabbed the bill and started to explain how she calculated OUTLOUD in front of the other table of customers. After that, she ignored my mom and she asked me if I get it? I said yes, and then go on explaining why I think she calculated wrong, and then she straight up cut me off, made an annoying noise with her tongue and said  "you don't get it", and explained herself OUTLOUD again. WTH?? Uh...why won't you let me talk. Not only did she not look at the bill, she kept thinking we got it wrong instead and felt annoyed by it when we should be annoyed. It's not that hard, but the whole time she thinks she's right--and the way she handled the situation was super rude and unprofessional.

I will never go back again.
author: Mandy C.

description:
I come here all the time to pick up food after work. I always call in my order and it usually is ready within 10 minutes. I am absolutely addicted to their baked pork chop over rice! Yummy. I used to really like eating at ABC but over the years they've changed. T28's baked pork chop is way better. I also like their Macau porky bun, their pork is always really tender. 

They also have a bunch of specials depending on the time/day you go. Usually comes with soup and dessert as well.
author: Cara N.

description: Fried Milk Dumplings FTW!
author: Joshua P.

description: Since this place is right around the block, I go here with my dad or friends whenever we don't feel like cooking. For the most part, I would say the food is pretty good, nothing to rave about, just your average americanized chinatown styled food. For being in the sunset district, I would say this place has pretty good deals. They also have really good portions. I've never finished a meal from here. Most of their noodles and rice plates are 7 - 10$ which is pretty cool considering the large amount. The only thing I dislike about this place is that even on a empty day, their meals are a  20-25 minute wait and you get the plates at different times. It really sucks when all your friends who ordered the same time as you are already eating and you still didn't get your plate, then after 20 minutes your plate finally arrives and everyone else is done....
author: Cindy L.

description: We found hair in our food oh and my Spam looked like it was moldy. That's enough for us to never come back here EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: selina n.

description: I came here for some rice noodle and pork and suet choi and it was okay. The pork was a little fat, but not too fat. I like the service. The hot noodles and the cold weather that day made it alot more merrier. The Beef chow fun is also good.
author: Selby C.

description:
This place isn't that great. The food is OK and the price isn't that great. But then I can say the same about the tables. They wipe it down with a wet towel that never gets washed. 

This place is good, when you are just feeling lazy to cook.
author: M C.

description:
Not sure what people are expecting when they come here but there's at least two things they do better than most others - tomato sauce w/pork chop and/or chicken AND the black sesame dessert.

Tomato sauce with pork chop is a quintessial hk cafe dish. Every place does it slightly differently. These guys do it with a smoky sweet tomato sauce that just comes out perfect every time. It's also beautifully executed with pork that's never overlooked topped with just the right amount of sauce.

And if ordering the combo, pick the black sesame dessert over the pudding. It's a better value and hits the spot every time.

And the soy milk there are made on-site I think. Always a winner.
author: E L.

description: If I want cheap chinese cafe food, I'd go here!
author: Cynthia D.

description:
For a couple of days while I was in San Francisco, I went to T-28 for breakfast before heading out to explore the city.  T-28 is the quintessential neighbourhood Hong Kong style cafe, serving local residents in the mainly Chinese area.  This restaurant also serves some Macanese cafe dishes also, and I'm guessing by the pictures of Macau hanging on the walls, the owners may be from Macau.

One morning, I had toast with condensed milk, and the other morning, I had Pidan Shourou Zhou.  The toast with condensed milk is basically just that - toast lathered with condensed milk.  This is a Macanese specialty and is always delicious.  Pidan Shourou Zhou is congee with "thousand-year egg" and lean shredded pork.  This is a very very common Cantonese breakfast.  Both of these dishes were good, but when compared with other places I've had them, not exactly exceptional.  Three stars.

For those of you who don't know where Macau is - it is a smaller city just about an hour-long ferry ride from Hong Kong across the Pearl River Delta.  It is a big gambling city and it was a Portuguese colony for 400 years until 1999.  There is some unique architecture and also some unique cuisine, but the biggest attraction is still the gambling (and of course.... everything else that comes with a gambling city...  use your imagination).

And now, Wikipedia links.  Because I always seek to educate.
Macau:  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macau
Pidan, or thousand-year-old egg:  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Century_egg
author: Radford T.

description:
=T-28 Bakery/ Cafe=

It's a pretty small place. The food was so-so. The portion was huge on my order. I went here with my friends and two of us ordered the Pork Chop with spaghetti with tomato sauce. The sauce was a little thick and didn't have that sweetness that tomato sauce would have. Not sure what it was. The pork chop was fried and it was tasty however. It was a lot of food. The meal came with a minestrone soup type, which had the perfect flavors. Our desert was mango pudding. I wouldn't have the mango pudding again.. It just didn't taste right. The mixture wasn't mixed fully because the bottom had some powder texture.

All in All, I'm willing to come back again to try other dishes. Nice little place.

PS: Their cold Lemon Tea is GOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOD!
author: Christopher J.

description: Knowing that this cafe had some bad reviews and from my friends great experiences, I hooked myself up to this place and not regretful that I did. I ordered some Macau style food and some American sided food: dumplings, soup, chow mein, and some sweet and sour appetizers. Aside from being cheap, clean, and it's friendly services, it tastes unique. I have been coming here for over a month and my only negatives are: porridge can be sometimes bland, restrooms can use more light, and seats to sit when it's packed. Overall, very enjoyable and I hope to see some fellow yelpers enjoying.
author: John W.

description: It's average/good and cheap.  It's like any other asian cafe.  The food is average to above average.  Good place on a really busy night where everywhere else is packed.
author: Gilbert L.

description:
Nice decor, pleasant service.
They specialize in H.K.and Macau food and snacks and it was tastey and a deal.
after 3pm , you can order various little snack specials. My friend and I ordered the pork chop and bun, comes with your choice of coffee, tea, or tea/milk. It came just like they said : a good sized thin pork chop, seasoned with garlic/salt and a decent sized sweetish bun/bread roll. 
We just made a sandwich out of it and enjoyed. $3.95, how do they make money? 
Don't know what lunch hour is like, but this place is ok.
 
Some of the other goodies on the menu are typical Hong Kong inspired versions of Euro/American fare. I like this place and will return often. Parking: ok, but you might have to walk a minute or two.
Modern looking decor, big screen T.V.'s.
author: Bert K.

description:
I came in here one morning to have breakfast with mi madre. I was looking forward to some Hong Kong style breakfast, but I guess we came in too late (11AM) since they switched the menu to lunch already. They have different entree specials every day of the week, which comes with a hot drink of your choice, soup of the day, and dessert.

I ordered the minced beef with egg over rice since I haven't had that in awhile and it happened to be a special that day. My soup came first and it was alright, nothing too special about their russian borscht. Then my entree came and it was a huge portion! I thought "wow, definitely worth the money!" so I start to stir it around to mix everything together. Lo and behold, there was a long strand of black hair running underneath everything! Disgusted, I told the server about it and she took it back. She brought me back another one in a bit and after losing half my appetite already, I couldn't really force myself to take more than a couple bites. It was kinda weird too because I don't ever remember the sauce for this rice plate to be .. sweet.

I think I'll stick to Tak Kee on Noriega from now on.
author: Joye C.

description:
The beef chow fun (dry style) here is soooo good.  And they give you a huge heaping portion of it.  I also come here for their rice porridge.  You get a good amount, and it's full of shredded pork and preserved duck egg.  They certainly don't skimp you on the portions or the ingredients.  I think T-28 is my restaurant of choice for those two dishes...they have the best beef chow fun and pork and preserved egg porridge in SF.  And to top it off, this place is cheap!

They also have daily specials, but I usually don't stray from my 2 dishes.  I've also gotten the chicken fried rice a few times, but i'd say that the chicken fried rice is average at best.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Before I start my review I must tell you all to try their Fried Milk. I thought it was good and kinda orgasmic (that's right..I used that word)...ok maybe not THAT orgasmic, but still good.  It's delicious when its fresh & hot so don't wait too long to eat it cuz it gets soggy fast.

ANYWAYS, I've actually been to this cafe before long long time ago in a galaxy far far awa-- nah im not going that far.....when the name was like White Elephant or Flying Elephant or something that to do w/ Dumbo, but anyways this place has turned into T-28 Cafe where you can get bakeries, dessert and oh yes HK Style Cafe rice plates and even restaurant style dinner where you can pick 2-3 dishes. 

The place is nice, but it annoys the hell out of me when flies start drag racing around the cafe like fast n the furious.  My friend commented on their variety of color coded menus which he thought it was confusing cuz he doesn't know which to choose, between the daily specials, regular menu or the happy hour menu.  All items are relatively cheap and serves decent portions.  Decent? what the hell am I saying?  It's big! (NOT what she said) Shoot I'm a big guy and I only finished half the plate.  Not to say the food is bad, but the portion is overloaded and packed with starchy rice.  (BTW I had their daily special Beef Curry)  The dish was good, can't say great, but its HK Style so its pretty much the same. Maybe my palate is screwed up? Who cares...it's filling.  Totally worth my dollar and dime and maybe pennies.  Definitely a good place to go back to once in a while, it's a good place to hang out w/ friends who's on a budget & craving for filling and not so traditional Chinese food.
author: Willis L.

description:
This place is seemingly always crowded,  but I have no idea why.

I came here previously on a lunch break from a former employer and was given only half an hour to eat. I was glad that they were speedy in making my won ton noodles. However, their food was only mediocre at best.

I went back today and tried out the fookien fried rice, singapore noodles, minced beef with egg noodles and beef chow fun.

The fookien fried rice was tasteless and bland, a real disappointment. If you're looking for good fookien fried rice, I suggest sun tea restaurant in noriega. 

The singapore noodles was alright, but nothing spectacular. It was a bit on the salty side.

The minced beef with noodles tasted like chef boyardee. No, really... It was runny tomato sauce and frozen veggies. They also decided to throw in hot dogs... Wtf! 

The best dish on the table was the beef chow fun but the beef wasn't tender but rather chewy. The noodles weren't bad though.

All in all, I wouldn't go back because the food isn't worth the wait nor is it worth putting up with the annoying patrons and the rude waitstaff.

The waitstaff is even worse than your stereotypical chinese restaurant. She didn't even know her own menu and squawked at us while we tried to order. She never smiled once nor did she show any kind of decency. 

This place just isn't worth it. Avoid and spend your money elsewhere.
author: Christina B.

description: The name T-28 just for their location (on Taraval and 28 Ave). But the Chinese name is something like "Little flying elephant from Macau". A typical Hong Kong - Western style cafe. The foods have the Portuguese mix since it's from Macau. It's always packed on Saturday and Sunday morning. Always like their daily special either on:  breakfast, lunch, late afternoon tea time, dinner or the after 9:30pm. You pick a set combo from the menu's list such as A, B, C, D, E...etc. Their shark fin soup is really delicious (of course it just imitation made from cellophane noodles, with mushrooms and pork).
author: Allen L.

description: Honestly, if you're expecting five star quality food, you probably shouldn't be walking in the door.  It's a Hong Kong style place, your Macau dishes, baked dishes over spaghetti or rice, sprinkled in with your typical must-have in any Chinese restaurant staples like chow fun, chow mein and fried rice.  Late night and mid day specials make it cheap and it does the trick, just don't expect much.  Food is OK.  Service is sort of what you should expect.  The chicken wings used to have a lot more of the red fermented beancurd taste, now it's barely there, but the wings are hot and juicy, so there's that.   Again, nothing is going to blow you away but you'll go away full and your wallet won't be crying after.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
I gots me a lunch special with soup, entree, drink and dessert.

Iced Milk Tea. It was pretty good, but I wished it was more bitter and tea flavored than sweet. 

Creamy Corn Soup. Pretty good, it filled me up pretty quick though I think because it was so creamy and heavy. 

Portugese Chicken Curry. With side of spaghetti. WAY better than the one I had previously at Shooting Star Cafe. This one was definitely more flavorful and tasted even better as leftovers. Om nom nom. I actually ended up taking most of it home as leftovers because I ate my friend's crab and fish fried rice instead. One critic I must add though is that I think they used the frozen drumsticks to make it because the texture of the chicken meat was a little different. 

Crab and Fish Fried Rice. With Roe. Pretty good, you could actually see the roe in it. Although it is a bit on the salty side. 

I didn't end up eating the dessert that came with the set because I was too full but you get to choose between a mango pudding and something else I can't remember.

One of my other friends actually said that this place used to be even better, unfortunately I may never know how good it was before. SADFACE.
author: Constance C.

description: Looked on yelp to see what's opened late (10:00pm) around the sunset area and T-28 popped up. Drove all the way here to find out that they're closed, but on yelp it said that they're opened until 12:00am. I understand if a restaurant closes 15-30 minutes early but 2 hours?! Won't try to come back here.
author: Li Z.

description:
The food is ok, but the waitress had very bad service. 
One of the waitress was so rude. She yelled at us when we tried to ask something politely!!! I can't believe people have bad attitude like that. No sevice at all.
author: DS T.

description:
Great porridge, especially when it's raining and late!

Ni how ma, baby!
author: Fourty F.

description:
Just because its crowded doesn't mean its necessarily good applies to this spot in the Sunset!!

So went to T-28 Bakery and Cafe recently and I have to tell you I had really high hopes for this place.  Whenever I have passed this place it is usually very crowded.  So when the craving for Chinese came I went.  It was not what I expected.  First the menu was confusing and huge.  Filled with lots of things I had either never heard of or a combo of American and Chinese foods which confused me.  I just wanted some good Chinese!  So I saw a curry beef hot pot on the menu and said yeah that sounds yummy.  The beef was so chewy I could not break it up in my mouth and the fat overpowered the meat.  I was not happy.  The flavor though was good and I wished there were more veggies in the hot pot for sure, but the beef experience left a really bad taste (literally) in my mouth!!

I am not sure I will be going here again anytime soon.  I believe the reason people flock here is because of the jook and the fact that this place is cheap (which now I know why...), but just because its cheap doesn't make me want to go again.  I may give it another chance in a while, but for now I won't be flapping my wings in their direction.
author: Heidi S.

description:
I like this place. I will have to try the porridge everyone is raving about....

I usually get the baked chicken steak w tomato sauce. Yummm! Though i NEVER finish it. The beef chow fun is good also (one plate is enough for 2 people. it is a large serving). The cold honey lemon is good (dong ling mutt). Service is OK, food is good, drinks are good, and they have a poster of my pageant in the front! Two thumbs up!!
author: Linda P.

description: I went here for lunch on Sunday and noticed the imitation fin soup is now $3.75, up from the $3.50 which I quoted on a prior review.  It's still a good deal.  Though it may be a bit higher than getting it at a dessert place (notably Eggettes and 37 Degrees), I think it's better tasting.  There may even be edge as far as the size of the portion.  I've gotten to think that, since they open until midnight every day (except for Tuesday, the day they're closed), I can opt to come here for that as dessert than the other two nearby places mentioned (though since it's waitress-serviced I'd have to leave her a tip).
author: H K.

description:
No matter how mediocre the food might be sometimes... I just can't stop coming here. This has become my go-to stop for cheap, satisfying food, at almost any time of day (they are open late). Great deals here at almost any time of day.... and believe me, I love to come here late.

My favorites are: any of their baked dishes over rice (especially love the seafood bake), fried pork or chicken w/ tomato sauce over rice, salt & pepper tofu, fried chicken wings, their Russian borscht, the samosas, pork & century egg porridge, and their beef chow fun. There's a few others that are good too but I've come here so often that I can't remember all the things I've ever had.

Down side is they are cash only and I survive mostly on plastic. :( At least I can hit up the BoA a few blocks down if I needed...
author: Melody S.

description:
T-28 boasts of a menu full of cheap, low quality food that is really unimpressive. There are other restaurants that offer way better food at even lower prices (D&A Restaurant). I've been here a couple times and was disappointed on both occasion. I had the macaroni with spam the second time. I can't recall what I had the first time; I most likely blocked it from my memory. The spam was disgusting, and the macaroni was equally as disgusting.

Save yourself from a stomachache and go somewhere else.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.

Cheap, delicious, Chinese food! 

I come here a lot, especially for those late night dinners when all the other Asian places are closed.  

Daily specials are $7.95 for soup of the day, entree, dessert, and drink.  You have four choices for entrees each day - usually a variety of fried rice and meat with sauce.  My favorite is the Black Pepper Sauce - IT IS THE BEST SAUCE and trust me, they give you ALOT of sauce.  

You can also switch the soup of the day to their Imitation Fin Soup for $0.50 more, which is what I always do.

On the most recent trip, I got Salt and Pepper Tofu, Steamed Mussels, and a daily special = $19.45 + $2.55 tip = $22.

Salt and Pepper Tofu was DELICIOUS, a YUMMY in my TUMMY! Crispy tofu with garnish.  It was cooked perfectly!!  

Steamed mussels...was not good. It was okay but being a seafood lover, I should have known better than to order mussels here.  Very garlicky but the mussels are definitely not the fresh kind, probably the frozen pack. Still okay but I probably will not be ordering it again. I'll just order another Salt and Pepper Tofu instead.

Entrees are huge; comes with rice or spaghetti; lots of sauce.  When getting the daily special with the entree, I usually save half for the next day - that's how huge it is. Meat is never overcooked, although there are some fatty parts but that's the part that taste the best right?

Another favorite of mine are their porridges, especially their late night special for $3.50 or something cheap like that.  BIG ASS DELICOUS bowl of porridge.  Need I say more?

If the restaurant is crowded, be prepared for a lack of customer service.  Usually it's only one waiter working so you may get impatient.  Food does come out quick though - usually 5-10 minutes.  If you do not speak the language, just wave your hands to get his attention.  Do not expect him to come over when you're about done.  

Best of all, they are always playing HK music videos or concerts.  I love it when they play the Beyond concert. Brings back childhood memories.
author: Joanna W.

description:
CASH ONLY

I can't believe T-28 charged me more than $6 for won ton noodle soup. I could have went to Won Ton House and got it for under $4!

Other than that T-28 is a pretty decent Hong Kong style cafe. Bf ordered their black pepper beef chow mien and he loved it. Ice lemon tea here isn't bad either. 

They do deliveries after 6pm.

Only annoying thing was one time when I was ordering to-go, the cashier told me that the total was $7.85 or something. I handed him a $20 and while he was getting the change I was looking through their menu to see what other stuff they had. The cashier without saying anything just handed me my change WHILE I was still looking at the menu. At least say something to get my attention. When I looked at him he had a "I've-been-standing-here-for-so-long-holding-your-change, I-want-to-murder-you" look on his face.  I don't have eyes on the side of my head.
author: Tracy A.

description:
Daily happy hours (ha mm cha) from 3-6.  Beware, the price on the menu is actually lower than the price they charge.  Maybe they should update their menu.

Got the beef noodle soup with a combination coffee/tea.  Less than $7 out the door.

Rants:
There was hair in my food.  Not just one strand, but more than one.  Perhaps from two different sources, as well.  Um, I guess hairnets are not required back there?
My beef was all fatty.  It looked gross.  I didn't bother tasting.

Sorry, there's no bouncing back from hair in food.
author: Jenny L.

description: I've been coming here on and off ever since it opened a few years back.  I like their large selection of noodles, rice plates, jook, sandwiches, and good old old fashion Chinese plates.  Really priced for cheap eats but not too shabby in my book.
author: Patrick C.

description: The specials are good. I prefer the fried rices. I like that they stay open late.
author: Mei-Fu L.

description:
The decor screams Macau but the food screams bloody murder...Not exactly Macau and not exactly Hong Kong...Sorta like a both got mashed together...Not saying it's not good...But also not saying it not bad...Hence the three stars on my review.

Most important thing you need to know. CASH ONLY!!! No money no talk. That said, let's talk about the food. Mediocre. Just in the middle. Not exactly WOW and full of pizazz and not exactly boring to the point of being plain. The food is decent. Like I've said before, it always depends on who the cook is that day and how he's feeling. Sometimes if the cook is angry and lost a ton of money on the ponies and the night before playing mah jong, you're in for a roller coaster of shitty food. If he's happy and made a buck, the food will sing off the plate. And then there are days when the cook takes a day off and the backup is there...Sometimes it's cool, sometimes it's not. If they could only manage to stay mediocre everyday...
