The portions are perfect. Not too big and not too small. You're getting your money's worth here. And the times this place runs is cool, too. Almost to midnight. Which is perfect because there are no bars near here so they don't need to stay open past midnight. Now the wait staff...I'm not sure what is going on with them but one of them is always in a bitchy mood. And it's never the same one that's a bitch each time. It's like playing musical moods with them. If you hate working there then quit. Simple as that. But on the days they aren't soo bitchy, they're on top of their game.

So for mediocre food, this place is great for you. Not in the mood for WOW? Then you should give them a try. Trust me, your boring ass will enjoy every minute of it here.
author: Anthony L.

description:
I had such high hopes for this place since it's a bakery (I love buns) and it has several kinds of congee/jook/porridge.  Unfortunately, they serve the worst congee I have ever had.  I did not know congee could be so bad.  They reached new depths.  I had the minced beef and egg congee.  I think they must have used a tablespoon of rice for 20 cups of water to make it.  I could not see rice - not even broken down rice.  It was so watery and goopy that it reminded me of what you'd get in a refugee camp or a Chinese construction site.  The minced beef tasted funny.  They put a raw egg in the congee.  I didn't realize it at first so when I started eating, I wondered what that thick, viscous substance was - it was raw egg white.  Yuck.  The best part of this goop was the fresh scallions.

I had the $3.75 breakfast special.  Along with the congee, it came with rice rolls (these were okay; they probably didn't make them, they come with a hoisin sauce) or fried Chinese donut and beverage of your choice.  I had the soy milk which was too sweet.  Despite the low price, I felt dissatisfied.  Rice is cheap, so I don't see why they're so skimpy about using it in their congee.  

If this is what the Macau twist is, yuck.  I hope that this isn't true for the sake of Macau.  For better congee, go to Ming Tai or Hing Lung.  Well, actually, go anywhere but here.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Decent HK food for a decent price. There's probably nothing better for it's type of food along the Taraval. 

Great place for snacking and drinking HK style foods. Service is alright, nothing noteworthy but not negative.
author: Dan S.

description:
I've been here twice, once to dine in, second to take out. Both times were disappointing. My first time was a long time ago when this place first opened. And it pissed me off so much because my dad and I were sitting near the window, and everytime the T-train came by, my seat shook. If i wanted my seat to shake while I have food in my stomach, I would ride a rollercoaster. 

My takeout experience was a little more recent. I ordered the curry chicken with rice. The curry was good but the whole meal and presentation of it was crappy. The chicken was in this big patty they didnt even bother to cut. As I'm used to and as normal restaurants do it, but not here, there were no potatoes or even bell peppers! Just chicken, curry and rice. WTH do i have to order curry chicken, potatoes and rice next time to get some potatoes included? For my boyfriend, I ordered this bbq pork + chow fun dish that he always gets. He said the bbq pork was cut too thin, but the gravy on the chow fun was better than the stuff they use at ABC. Price was about normal, 15 bucks for both dishes. 

Last to mention, this place is supposed to be open late night. Not sure how late but my friend says it is. Oh and cash only. 

1 star because the food tastes decent and 1 star for open late night.
author: Karen C.

description: Affordable eating with a great selection. Let me start by saying they have food from all over Asia. Honk Kong, Burma, Macau, and China. They also have daily specials for each day of the week. Nice selection of drinks and they are open late. But the best part of this place is the Fried Milk! It's a milky, vanilla, coconut, soft inside that's deep-fried. C'mon deep-fried need I say more?
author: T L.

description: This place is OK. Me and my family/friends go here sometimes just to grab some quick food. I don't notice the waiters that much because they come and go a lot and hardly checked in on us. The food isn't that great or bad at all, but something is wrong. Sometimes you have to wait a while just to get a table, then ahold of a waiter. Since you have to park on the streets, sometimes you may have to go around for 15 minutes just to find parking.
author: Jeffy Y.

description:
The waitress with two rings on her right ear lope had a bad attitude.  Really bad.  She did her  "job" begrudgingly, doing you a favor, like a pouting teenage.

Also the sign on the wall says something idiotic in Chinese: "The first time being ignored, your loss. The second time being ignored, it is because we did not do our job." What?

"From your patronage, we have our job."  Please explain this part of the sign to the waitress.  She shouldn't be here!
author: Eric L.

description:
Small snacks and cafe drinks. I went with a bunch of friends and when our food arrived everyone's reaction was "hm." 

I'll probably just not go there too often since it was....just alright.
author: Janelle H.

description:
This place is so hit or miss!

Food: So I've had some NASTY stuff here. I had some pork chop rice before and it just tasted gross. But then I tried the Portugese Chow Mein and Baked Chicken Steak with Tomato Sauce and they were really tasty. It's not bad if you get the meal when they have one you like! Comes with a corn chowder, milk tea, and mango dessert (which I have to mention tastes gross). But honestly, it isn't that bad... you just have to stick with the tried and true!

Service: Typical asian service. Very whatever. "Hit and run" style. To be expected.

Parking: On a busy street, where there aren't many spots. You probably have to park blocks away or hope and pray someone leaves right away when you get there lol.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Watch out for the bones.  My curry chicken had bone chips that were like mines ready to crack my teeth.  T-28 serves decent Hong Kong-style cafe food.  I came here with a couple of friends, and between us, we tried imitation shark's fin soup, Singaporean noodles, and Portuguese style curry chicken.

Don't expect to eat healthy here.  Overall, the portions were big and the food was a bit rich.  The soup and the noodles were alright.  The curry, while tasty, was overloaded with coconut milk.  The food could have been better, but as a neighborhood dive with a lot of menu items, I want to give this joint another chance.
author: Tony L.

description:
I went there around 11:00 AM on a Friday for brunch with my coworker.  The place wasn't crowded at all - quite the opposite in fact. Parking around Taravel is annoying. The name itself was pretty interesting, you won't be able to forget where it's located T -28, Taravel and 28th.  

Anyway, food-wise and seating during brunch is pleasant.  They'll seat you right away.  They have a special everyday which is nice because of the deal it provides.

I got the breakfast special - option E.  Preserved Egg & Salted Pork Porridge with Chinese Donut and coffee & milk tea w/ condensed milk all for around $6 (tip included).  

The porridge came piping hot and the coffee & milk tea was okay.  Overall, a good place to go for cheap, decent food.  However, nothing stood out to me.  If you go, I recommend the porridge during a non-busy time so the food comes hot and of good quantity & quality.
author: Nina M.

description:
T28 is a fairly new restaurant in the vein of D&A Cafe (on Clement) - an extensive menu of Chinese dishes, strange macaroni combos, and delicious rice porridge - but much better food and a lot more sanitary as you'll see by their proudly displayed Health Inspection rating of 99.

The Breakfast Combos are the best deals at T28... for $3.75 you get a personal-sized bowl of rice porridge with either fish or sliced pork and a side of fresh rice rolls. Also try the Macau style pork buns. (The wall decor features framed photos of Macau.)

Open Daily from 7:30am to 12 Midnight. Free Delivery in the evening with orders over $20. T28 is Cash Only - Good food, Great prices. Enjoy! :)
author: Be N.

description:
This restaurant has very good rice porridge (jook) which is the only thing I get.   From the looks of it, I think the rest of the food is just average but their rice porridge is bomb and the Chinese donuts are really good.  

Go here for the rice porridge and maybe try something else.  The service is pretty average, nothing too great and the prices are good and cheap.

Also, I discovered they have Hi Tea everyday from 3-6pm, they have gret specials for $3-$4.  What I always get is the pork rice porridge w/preserved egg, all for $3.50... Yum!
author: Michi R.

description: Atmosphere is great, portion size is amazing and if you get the house special you get your choose of hot drinks and dessert. Mango pudding is delicious!!
author: Julie H.

description: The most terrible food I ever tried in Taraval st!! Bad service and rude attitude of the waitress! The fried beef dry noodle is even worse than I did. Will never come back again.
author: Ll L.

description:
Nice little place off the corner of Taraval and 28th - I'm guessing that's what the T-28 stands for, since it's name in Chinese is totally out of left field. 

It's going to be my new go-to place for a quick, fuss free meal, after 8:30pm. Why? Between 8:30pm to midnight (Mon-Sat) and 8:30pm - 11pm (Sun) they have this specials menu where appetizers go for under $4, and some mains like fried macaroni, chow fun and the instant noodle fair go for under $5. And the portions are decent!

I decided to go with a Saturday special - Chicken Steak with Tomato Sauce on Rice, which comes with a soup (today it was Cream of Corn with Chicken, not bad), a hot drink (milk tea was decent, contrary to other reviews) and dessert (red bean + coconut cream + sago) - all for under $8. Not bad at all. The main dish was huge - would've fed 3 of me. 

Service was decent too, so I'm guessing it's better to come off peak. Parking is a breeze at 8.30pm. Closed on Tuesdays.
author: v w.

description:
This is a Macau Cafe, so you should try the Pork Bun Sandwich, which is what macau is known for. Its pretty good here and can compare to macau's.  AND CHEAP!

However, the BEST time is to go for breakfast.

Their jook [congee or porridge] is the best in the Sunset, its not too gooey, not too watery, not too salty with msg, not too bland, its just right. but REALLY STEAMING HOT. so watch out.

With a jook, you can also pick a side order, of oil stick [chinese donut] OR Crazy Sauce churng fun[--noodle wrap--]with hoiseen sauce, peanut butter sauce and hot sauce ALL MIXED TOGETHER hence its called crazy sauce. THATS MY FAVE side btw.

Your breakfast also comes with a complimentary drink.

3 people, my mom leaves $15 thats INCLUDING tip!  what a deal and you leave with your tummy SO full!!

There are also happy hours when food is crazy cheap, but you cant pay that price if you want to take your food to-go.

Daily Dinner specials are about $7.00, that includes:
-drink 
-starter soup, if you add $.50 you can have shark fin soup
-main entree
-dessert

id choose this place over ABC anytime, unless i have the munchies at 2am and this place is closed..
author: kim w.

description:
Jeeze what is up with all these hybrid restaurants these days? This place is exactly like other places I have wrote about earlier such as D&A Cafe, S&E Cafe and ABC Bakery... man what is up with all the names of these places anyway? I just noticed that. But anyway this place reminds me of the ever growing population of Asian Americans in San Francisco and how many people actually come here because of the decent prices. I guess every major street in the Sunset should have a place like this. Taraval, Noriega, and Irving just to name a few.

Coming here one day I just wanted something simple. An order of rice porridge which came out luke warm to my surprise and a side dish of chow mein. I wasn't too pleased with my experience as you can see due to the fact that the noodles were cold and greasy and tasted like they were made the day before. The same goes for the "jook" which was too watery and had no taste to it whatsoever. It was like I was drinking plain white rice. That isn't something that appeals to me very well so I can honestly say I shall try to avoid this place at all costs unless I'm dragged there by someone who really wants to eat here.
author: Jason Y.

description:
T-28, referring to its corner of Taraval and 28th Avenue location, is my favorite spot for Chinese Soul Food. 

"Ummmm, what Soul food?" you ask?

It is a term I coined that refers to good, cheap Chinese food that makes you feel very very VERY happy inside.  It should technically be called Hong Kong Soul Food but that does not have the same ring.

I guess I am a creature of habit as I always get the same three things when I'm here: fried macaroni, turnip cake, and iced honey lemon tea.  The macaroni is stir-fried with small cubes of spam, veggies and seasonings that give the dish a glossy brown finish.  Hit it with some hot chill sauce and expect me to ignore you for the rest of the meal.  Just kidding. Not really.  Expect a pretty generous serving of the turnip cake appetizer.  Slightly crispy external, soft internal with a smattering of pork bits inside. YUM YUM.  I wash everything down with a tall glass of the honey lemon tea.  Make sure you crush the lemon rings into the bottom of the glass cup with the long spoon to release all the lemony juices.  Yes, there was a reason for the spoon.    

I am sad that this place does not have better reviews.  I guess it will just be my gem to keep.  Mine.  My precious. :)
author: Rose J.

description:
How do I love thee?  Let me count the ways...
For when you unfailingly serve up some good jook and chinese donut on weekend mornings (Asian version of "brunch")
For when you are open late at night (past 10 pm!) 
For the consistency of quality that you serve (not the greatest, but consistently not the greatest!)
For the unpretentious service (seriously, no bs here, I come, I eat, I pay, I leave)
For the unbelievably low price, prices so low you can afford to order 2 entrees!

I hope you'll stick around for a long time...
author: Yohanna B.

description:
Ok went here on Saturday 10/25/08 we got there at 7pm , the restaurant
holds about 50  people and the place was full, they have hk style of
dinning much like DNA Cafe. I had the Chicken Steak with pepper sauce,
very good and tasty. looks like the noodle is a hot seller as many table
ordered various dishes of noodle. other news to know, parking is easy and
service is fast and friendly.

Mr. Peabody system
food            4
volume       4
service        4
experience 4
parking        4 (easy )
author: Howard J.

description: Avoid this place like the plague.  I got food poisoning here.  I ordered the porkchop bun.  I don't know how the other items are, but I don't want to know.
author: A L.

description:
I went here tonight after 9pm with my roomates for a late night dinner.
I was impressed by how cheap everything was, especially their menu that is only offered from 9-12. Dishes and appetizers were priced very cheapy (under $4!). 
I ordered the macoroni soup with spam and the chicken chow mein. The chow mein was very good, not too salty and also came with thin noodles which was something that I am not used to. The macoroni soup was also not bad (probably something I could easily stir up at home but was satisfying). 
So, by the end of our meal I was satisfied with my choices. However I do wish that the waiters would be a little more attentive. I had to literally flag them down for water, boxes, and our bill. And plus, they didn't understand anything I asked when I questioned about several things on the menu, but hey, thats ok as long as my food is good.
author: Miss H K.

description: Ewww!  Ok, I only tried the steak in the sizzling black iron plate and it was the worst steak I have ever had.  I knew beforehand they would probably overcook it because most Chinese restaurants do (I know because I frequent many of these cafes) and my instincts were spot on.  They didn't have the filet mignon but instead regular steak so I decided against my better judgement to try it.  I specify in great detail and in Chinese that I want it completely rare, noting that if I spoke English, they would not know what the heck I'm saying and I didn't want to take any chances.  They gave me this really weird look like "are you sure you want it that rare".  I nodded and said yes.  Well, about 15 minutes later my steak came and it was completely cooked and dried like a desert inside.  I bet if I threw it in the wall it would crack it.  I laughed because all this time the ladies looked at me weird and was shocked that I want a steak rare but WTF, it's not like its rare anyways and it's cooked completely.  So what is the difference if I said I want it medium rare, medium well or completely cooked?....NOTHING.  It would come out exactly looking the same.  That is just how Chinese cafes do it...LOL.  Seriously, I think they assume everyone must want it cooked well just because these prudes want it that way.  On top of that, the meat tasted disgusting.  I think it was not stored properly.  So I left most of it untouched and they looked at me like "what happened".  I gave them back this look like really, can you not see it's so cooked.  This confirms it.  Sorry but Chinese cafes can't cook a good steak.  They don't listen and they'll cook it that same no matter what you say.  And they use the cheapest meat available.
author: Hairy Potmaker C.

description: I often frequent T-28 whenever I visit my friend who lives 2 blocks away. I think we like coming here because we always leave feeling like we got a deal. The food is so cheap! It's not the best food, but it tastes okay and one order is usually two servings. They also have daily specials that include soup, drink, and dessert!
author: Eric L.

description: I like coming here because it's convenient and usually, pretty easy to find parking.  It's a little corner cafe that's supposed to be serving dishes from Macau, but honestly, it's just like any other typical HK Cafe.  They're pretty busy on the weekends, especially in the morning because they have a $3.75 special if you get there before 11:30.  Mmm...I must say, I'm pretty satisfied with their morning special!  You get a choice of porridge/noodles/sandwiches + drink and then an additional .75 if you want to add a side order.  Come on, it doesn't get any cheaper than this!  However, if you were to ask me if their other dishes are good...I would have to say they're only so-so.
author: Melissa T.

description:
It's finals week and my friends and I have been studying for 8 hours straight, and its about 10 pm! What choices do we have to satisfy our appetite, on a small budget!? There's seniores but pizza wasn't hearty enough, there's lucky penny.. but ehhh.... and then bam T-28! What a great whole in the wall... from 9pm-11pm they have night special consisting of appetizers, noodles, congee, sandiwches... etc... and they range from $3.30 to $3.90! 

The Baked Mussels with Garlic CHECK
The Steamed Mussels with Garlic are CHECK
Wonton Noodle Soup CHECK
Thousand Year old egg with pork congee CHECK
Beef Chow fun CHECK
Fried wonton CHECK
Imitation Shark fin CHECK
Pork Chop Sandwich CHECK

THE BILL COMES AND ITS ONLY $31! hahaha CRAZY! all that food for $31! feeding 3 of us as well! where else can you get that!? NO WHERE!
author: Brian P.

description:
This place serves cheap, quick Macau style food - although I don't think it's that authentic or nearly as good as the real thing.  Portions and prices are decent, but you're not going to find five star food here.

However, my family likes coming here bc it's cheap and fills ya up.  

- Beancurd Deep Fried Chicken Wings: 8 pieces... nice and crispy.  $5
- Portuguese style mackerel fried rice ... flavorful, delicious, and part of the Sunday special
- Baked Seafood with Cheese and Pineapple: very bland

Their noodles are usually very bland so I avoid them.  If you get their daily special for $7.15, you get a drink, soup, entree, and dessert.  Not too bad.

CASH ONLY!

This place can't compare to Macau Cafe though! =D
author: Michelle W.

description:
Service: They neglected our soup that came with the meal. assumed that since 2 people didn't order the set dinners that they did not want anything to drink either.  

Food: Pros: my Portugese chicken cutlet was good. Dessert was good. Soup was good.
          Cons:  my man's beef was undercooked. It was pink and chewy. He's usually one of those people who finishes everything off the plate and tears off the "bad" part of the veggie to not waste food. He left all the beeft on the plate this time.  I don't think eating raw meat like that was to his liking.

Next time, please cook the meat a little better.....
author: A L.

description: Just came back to this wonderful place for lunch for the second time and treated myself to a yummmmmmmmy Abalone & Chicken Porridge!!!!!!!! First time for me that, I have ever tried a Abalone & Chicken Porridge at T28 Bakery & Cafe and it had a really good taste to it... I LOVE IT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: William B.

description:
cheapp place for early breakfast. yummy jook and hot soy bean milk drink all for 3.45 whooopeee

tried spam and egg macaroni also, was...interesting....salty....

got lunch take out once tooo, not bad, they give a lot too.

never tried other stuff but close by so will definitely try other things next time
author: Christine M.

description:
I've always drove by or walked by this cafe but have never stepped foot into it until today. Ate here for lunch with a group of friends. The cafe is quite small and decent looking. Not dirty or shabby either. Just like most hong kong style cafes, their menu offers daily specials. Today their special was  the Portuguese fried rice,  short ribs in pepper sauce or the pork and chicken steak in tomato sauce. Each entree is served with rice or spaghetti, a bowl of soup and a drink.

 A friend ordered the minced beef with egg rice plate, and it looked like chef boyardee poured over rice. It didn't taste very good- he didn't had an appetite to eat it either because there was a confusion/mix up with his order so he had to send his first order back which convinced him to think that the 2nd plate they brought out to him had spit in it. 

Another friend ordered the salted fish and diced chicken fried rice and that was yummy! 

A friend and I both ordered the short rib w/ pepper sauce with rice and I must say that it was the best on our table. 

Their lemon iced tea isn't bad either, but I've had better elsewhere.

Not a bad place to dine at for lunch. Not sure if they open late....they might? Its definitely a better alternative if I had to choose between T-28 and  ABC.

Oh and the bill was really cheap. There were 6 of us, though not all of us ordered an entree, everyone DID order something.  The tab was only 41 dollars.

Cash Only.
author: Jenny K.

description:
i remember coming here a long time ago, but i never knew the name was t-28. The first time i came to this place, i had a Fookeen fried rice. it was decent but nothing special when compared to other restaurants or places that served the same dish. 

the other thing that i remembered is that they played the Jay Chou concert on their plasma. 

I've never tried anything else here, but if i do come and visit again, i'll update the review.
author: Eric Y.

description:
T-28 Cafe gives you fond memories of eating in HK/Macau type places.
Remember Firewood or Cafe de Coral?
Fast type food served to your table instead of waiting in line near the kitchen counter for pick-up.  Its cheap eats so don't expect too much.
The specials are decent but portions may be small if you order a la carte on the afternoon tea.  Rice plates or noodles are good choices.
Good for late nights or odd ball times!
author: Eric Y.

description:
hong kong style food!

i had the Portuguese pork chop w/ spaghetti as part of their daily special. the milk tea went down smoothly, the russian borscht soup was delicious and plentiful, the portuguese sauce was decent, pork chop was okay, and the mango pudding was good. my granny just had a red bean ice and it was huge! afternoon tea special 3-6pm was only $2.25 and most places offer it at $3 in a smaller cup. all in all, this place has cheap prices and big portions, and i would come again.
author: Carrie L.

description: its bang for the bucks, ate here couple of times for happy hour... but sometimes little after i order something off there special... oh man i dunno what the hell was i eat, it was some noddle soup... guess i wont order that again, haha....
author: JessePanda C.

description: We ordered a baked fish dish and a baked seafood dish. The seafood dish was supposed to have pineapple in it. But we could only find tiny bits of it. The food was edible, that's all. Also, if you are giving out free pudding, everyone should get it, right? We didn't.
author: YM L.

description:
Yays: I like this place. When I went with my mom, we had good & attentive service, great shark fin soup (only add $0.50 more to the daily special!) and a pretty yummy baked seafood dish!  Mmmmm...

Nays: I noticed that they add additional $ for take-out or something. Hmmm...
author: J T.

description:
This is the place to be for cheap jook for breakfast. The breakfast special comes with your choice of jook, a drink, and either Chinese doughnut or rice noodle roll for only $3.95.

I usually get the minced beef jook which comes with a raw egg, doughnut and the cofee tea. My boyfriend loves the salted pork bone jook with fresh soy milk.
author: Jennie N.

description:
I don't really like cafe Chinese(-American) food.  But my fellowship group from school came here last night, so yea...

I came here with my folks and brother about a month ago once prior to last night.  It's a pretty small place.  People say it's cheap here, but I don't really get a  "OMG IT'S ONLY THAT MUCH?" reaction.  The food is average.  Last night, I ordered their daily special for $7.95 - Chicken Steak w/ Spaghetti in Tomato sauce along with Corn w/ Chicken Soup and Hot Tea.    If i would of paid an extra 50 cents, I could of upgraded my soup to Imitation Shark Fin Soup.  

BAD SERVICE!  I had to request my hot tea three times.  By the time I got it, I was nearly done with my meal and ready to go.  Therefore, making it hard to be able to relaxingly consume my hot tea since there was no time to let it cool down.

They're also not very articulate in describing what each item in their menu is, so you better be top notch in your Chinese.
author: Leslie Y.

description: Cheap and decent food in the Sunset district, they have all these HK and Macao style food.  The Pork chop bun is a bit flat, the fried chicken is bland, but all the noodles, rice dishes, porridge and all the other HK style snacks and drinks are all pretty good, we especially like the Burmese noodles, the broth is very tasty.  Service is quick and efficient,  decent place for cheap eats...
author: Raymond N.

description: I like this place. It's not super fantastic, but I mean, it's alright depending on what you choose. I remember coming here once for some sort of rice plate and it was super good. I don't remember what it was though. But last time I came, I ordered the pineapple fried rice cause I didn't know what else to eat. I was sad that there were only a few chunks of pineapple. =[ It came with cream of corn soup which was okay. My brother ordered the curry beef with rice which was SOOO GOOD!! At the end of the meal, you get dessert, I suggest getting the sesame paste thing. It was very yummy, unlike any other I've had. The sesame paste was smooth, not chunky like other places, and it was rich with teh sesame flavor. Good price for the amount of food you get.
author: Annie W.

description: This is your typical Chinese-American cafe. There's nothing really special about it. I get food here once in a while and it's usually pretty okay. Their food is not awful nor is it very tasty. Their lunch specials are pretty worth it. For $7.95 you can get an entree, soup, and a drink. What more could you ask for with that price? If you eat in, make sure you have patience, especially if they are busy. I've been ignored here maybe twice and it isn't very great. I make eye contact with a waiter and he doesn't even bring me a menu. When you order take out like a sandwich with fries, they only give you a tiny container of ketchup, which is barely enough. But other then those couple of things, I'd say it's a quick and cheap lunch/ dinner.Oh yes, if you don't speak Chinese that may be a downside too!!
author: Rebecca T.

description: absolutely great. owner is very hardworking and very nice. nice people and pretty nice food.
author: Jean W.

description:
I'm only giving this place 5 stars because of the experience I had eating this food once I'd taken it home.

Unfortunately, my first visit to this little cafe was the one our of few days when I'd totally lost my sense of taste and smell (sick as a dog)... I went walking along Taraval with my boyfriend on our third anniversary, and we decided to drop by and grab a bite to eat.

I ordered the lunch special, or whatever the menu was called for the food ordered around 2:30PM... We actually wanted to order from the Hi - tea time menus posted on the outside window, but after asking the server, she replied in a semi-angry tone "THREE O CLOCK"... I'll bet that if we spoke cantonese like every single other customer in the place, she'd have let us slide.. damnit. (Too bad my bf only speaks mandarin! ) 

Anyway, I ordered the beef curry dish over rice, can't remember the exact name, but it's the special for wednesday, and my bf ordered the chicken steak over rice. His chicken came out, at least 30 minutes before mine, because they forgot my order, but remembered every other part of my meal (drink/soup).. we asked the woman about it, and she actually apologized and said she'd get the dish out in 5 minutes! (Unexpected, considering the cold, dismissive way she'd treated us only a bit earlier)

I admit, I could barely taste the milk tea, soup, or dessert I had while eating there, but when my beef came out, I could actually taste some of the spicyness, and the sauce looked INCREDIBLE. I've had curry at many other asian restaurants in my life, but it never looked nearly as fresh and not.. canned or bottled as I'd expect. (it didn't have a too-yellowish, fake looking color to it either, it looked homemade) My boyfriend tried some of it and said it was at least 25 times better than what he'd ordered (haha... the tomato sauce on his chicken steak looked like orange globular vomit). Anyway, I was impressed with the quality of my dish -- fantastic looking, and i was getting hints of savory, spicy flavor. I boxed up the extras, and took them home.

After clearing my sinuses with some powerful medicine, I decided to heat up my leftovers that night. And.. that is where the 5 stars is coming from.. IT WAS INCREDIBLE~~... Almost too good for words, it had such amazing flavor for a dish that seemingly came from a mediocre quality place, and after this pleasant surprise, I decided we MUST go back!... 

Anyway.. order the beef and curry dish with rice!! Better than any I've EVER had.
author: Christine K.

description:
3.5 stars - small restaurant situated in the sunset right on Taraval and 28th..thus T-28...ahhhh!  

rice plates (baked pork chop in tomato sauce) and noodle dishes (black pepper beef chow mein is one of my favs), good portions, reasonable prices and open til midnight (hard to find in the area).  similar to cafe bakery....somewhat.  parking is rough as is most places on taraval.  now if they only delivered!!  

......i'll be back 

(please tell me you got that)
author: Craig I.

description:
Pretty new (recently renovated?) HK cafe, most people ate noodles, served on a plate with either meat curry or steak

I ordered the chicken coconut noodle soup and was pretty spooked to find it laid flat on a plate with a bowl of curry (way coconut). Verdict: meat has been standing there so somewhat not warm (even kinda cold), it's been stewing a while, too much causing some of it to be tough, it wasn't all dark meat either

I thought it was served with way too much noodles but I ended up eating almost the whole dish (gluttony), I found the noodles quite good, thick 

Dish grade: b-, $6.80

I would have to go back to try them steaks or what not, over noodle (just say it, it's spaghetti)
author: xo x.

description: Portuguese sauce is D-LICIOUS!!!!!  It always makes my nancy happy!
author: Joseph C.

description: My Boyfriend and I went there after school, the waitress was so mean, seemed like dont even wanna serve us. and as we ordered our food, she was sitting at the corner table to chat with the other workers... we asked her to get check after eating ,she was not responding neither...
author: Annie H.

description: This is my 100th review at Yelp and I choose to use it on this restaurant.  I go to this place on Sundays to avoid the crowds.  There's never a a line.  There's always daily specials for $7.95 (?) which includes choice of 4 daily entrees, salty house soup, spaghetti or rice, choice of drink (I usually choose between Hong Kong tea or hot fresh soy milk-reminds me of childhood), and very nasty mango pudding.  You probably ask why I go here.  It's comfortable and homey food.  You sit next to the window and you watch the L-Taraval go by.  You see families eating together.  You can actually hear conversations.  The baked seafood has fake crab meat and calamari, one mussel or two.  It's not overpowering and not too much gravy.  The seafood rice is not so greasy.  The Portuguese curry chicken is really good.  It includes two cups of rice.  You have to take home; it's too much.  The shrimp rice noodle comes with both hoisin sauce and sesame sauce., which reminds me of Hong Kong.  The won ton lo-mein looked really good.  The service is typical Chinese.  You're in luck if they are friendly.  They are not there to make your day, just to give you your food.  This is hard work and long hours, so give them some understanding.  Did I mention, cheap!  Cash only, but you can afford it.
author: Helen L.

description:
I've only been here twice so far. 

First visit/dinner-- HK milk tea, pretty damn good. Ordered some fried rice off the day's special menu. Also pretty damn good. I think it had shrimp in it. Maybe it was a seafood fried rice. 

Second visit/lunch, packed -- Got the HK milk tea, of course. Again, pretty damn good. Curry beef brisket rice noodle soup. I got the wide rice noodles. They were fresh and succulent. The curry at first tasted a bit odd, but once I stirred it more into the broth, it was quite good. The beef brisket was exactly right -- tender, a bit chewy, tendon-y, fatty in the right amount. 

Now I want to go back and try the normal beef brisket noodle soup, the fish ball noodle soup, and also the jook. I see mixed reviews of the jook on Yelp, but I know how subjective that can be. 

In fact, I've had a cold for the past week. Perfect time to test the jook.
author: Lola X.

description: I like this place.  First of all, they give you a lot of food.  So, if I'm really hungry, this is a good place to go.  Secondly, the food they serve is different than most Chinese restaurants.  It's Macau style cuisine - now, I have never been to Macau, so I can't comment on its authenticity.  But, I like trying new dishes, and they have quite a few.  Some I liked a lot, some I wasn't too crazy about.  The place is pretty clean, and the service is pretty efficient.  Food always arrives hot, and seems freshly prepared.  Sometimes the worker's English isn't too great, but hey, if you are ordering ravioli and the chef only speaks Italian, that's a plus, right?
author: Marty C.

description:
This place is open late (a very good and rare thing) and fairly trendy to the young Asian crowd. A strange and huge menu of things (at least to this white boy), a diner look, and a flat screen playing Japanese music videos. I really love the coconut-jelly-icee-drink-thing they have. Your bound to find something you like.. but could also trip onto something a bit weird if your experimenting. The servers aren't much help in deciding since they barely speak English. Some of the treatment there makes me thing they are a bit racist and don't want white people coming in, I don't know.
My number one complaint with this place is it is FREEEEZING! I'll come there at 11PM or so and it feels like they MUST have the air conditioning on. I literally am shivering whenever I leave that place. Dress like a snowboarder and it'll be an adventure.
author: Eric A.

description: Just went to this place with my family of 4 for dinner tonight.  We ordered the Friday specials with 4 choices to choose from.   For $7.95, we got a hot entree with choice of rice or spaghetti that came with soup of the day, a drink and dessert.  What a deal!!!  Food was good, price was great, service was good and the place was clean.  I prefer this place over Cafe and Bakery on Noriega.  By the way, this place accepts cash only, no credit card.
author: Avocadoagogo L.

description: We come here often Friday nights. Food is merely ok at worst and alright at best. But it's cheaper than say King of Thai up the street if you're in that neighborhood and are stuck out late. You'll want to just order off their specials menu though for the best value. If you insist enough, they'll even let you order special combos that are only for other days. Service is decent, but it can get a bit loud sometimes since its common for big groups to come in late.
author: Peter W.

description: First of all: the people who work here are so hard-working and friendly, and I really admire their commitment to good customer service.  Okay.  So this might not be the place for a nice, romantic, fancy candlelight dinner for two, but if you are looking for some good, hot Chinese food that is cheap and quick, this is definitely the place to go in outer sunset/parkside area.
author: Jessica H.

description: I went here with my best friend recently and got the Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings. Wow. A must try for everyone.
author: Melissa B.

description:
is it a strange coincidence that hk cafes/bistros make good chow fun?  their chow fun is pretty good too, with a lot of "wok hay" (although broadway bistro in millbrae is a tad bit better - for you chow fun lovers).  this is also a good place to come for porridge, i like the "pei dan sow yuk" - thousand year egg w/ pork meat.  i forgot what the prices were but if you come after 9 p.m. it's cheaper, but you have to eat in, no take outs (bummer!).

ps. 
try to stay away from the spaghetti if you can.....
author: Paulina C.

description: Very good food at  reasonable price.  They don't have MSG in the food but as with all Chinese and Asian food. They are greasy but this place is average on that part.
author: W. L.

description: Just browsing T-28's menu is an adventure.  The atmosphere is casual and comfortable, and the food is tasty.  Every sauce they make is delicious!  I highly recommend the chicken with black pepper sauce!  The portuguese style curry chicken is equally incredible... just watch for the bones.  Be sure to bring cash.
author: Christena T.

description: I ordered their Fried chicken steak and pork chops all with portuguese sauce and I love it.  They have a lot of variety there and prices are fair.
author: Nancy L.

description: Been here multiple times, and it wasn't good. I remember the first and second time being quite horrible, and don't recall the third time with the won ton noodles. Their beef chow fun was basically burnt. Service is laid back, but I will say that the place is decent on its CLEAN scale. It looks a lot nicer than other diner type places. Tvs that plays Asian music videos. Overall, not my choice.
author: Elaine H.

description: I really like this place!  It is open pretty late (except Tuesdays) and has a large, authentic Hong Kong/ Macau menu.  I've tried the Bean Sprout Chow Mein, which is great, the Fried Milk Dumplings, also great, the porridge, really good, the shark fin soup is awesome, the garlic mussels, which are really good, but maybe a little too garlicky for me, and the chicken wings, which have a great texture, but maybe need to be a little more flavorful.   The wait staff is attentive, and the surroundings are really casual, but not dirty.  The flavors really remind me of my first time in China, and whenever I'm in Sunset, T-28 is an automatic choice.
author: Craig M.

description: When they first opened, the food was plentiful and good. However, after a while, the food plates didn't taste as good anymore, and it got a little skimpy. You can say this is supposed to be authentic hong kong style food, but It's far from it in my opinion. At least the place seemed clean and sanitory.
author: Andrew W.

description: The food here is alright but I could definitely see myself giving them 4-stars had I come here after a night of a drinking. HK style rice (or noodle) dishes that is decently priced and tastes pretty good. The huge portions are definitely a big plus. My suggestion would be to order one of the Specials since it includes a house soup, hot drink and dessert for a few cents more than most regular dishes. OR, the best is if you come after 9:00pm. Then you can order meals that are less than $4. Score!
author: James C.

description: If your into HK and Macou food this is a great place to visit. Food here is cheap and tasty, but very greasy, creamy, thick, etc.... I stop coming here only when i realized what I was eatting (ox tongue), which than scared me away. I use to love eatting ox tongue, until i began to realize i was eatting a tongue.
author: David M.

description:
my gramps favorite place to get jook in the morning. and damn it is cheap. plus if you get the jook with salted egg and black egg (which is my fave), they give you a whole black egg. A WHOLE BLACK EGG!!

unlike those cheap shysters who only give you small slivers of egg in their jook, yeah i'm looking at you our court on clement!

cash only okay.
author: Melanie C.

description:
OK, I've debated on how to start this review and I think I've come to a conclusion:

What do you think when you hear (or read) "shredded chicken"?  Anyone?  Shredded, like small pieces right?  Shredded?  

So I ordered some instant noodle with "shredded chicken" and my food comes out one minute later.  What do I see?  I see a bowl of soup with instant noodles and a piece of chicken steak that's been cut up into 5 pieces.  WTF.  Tell me that's not "shredded chicken".  So I asked the person, what is this, I ordered shredded chicken.  And the person insists this is shredded chicken.  Um.. no it's not.  So we asked what they serve on the other noodle forms that have "shredded chicken" as the meat option, and surprisingly enough he says it's really shredded.  WTF again.  So why can't you put that meat in this soup because I ordered SHREDDED CHICKEN?  It costs extra apparently.  WTF!  Ok.. so I want to change my order because this menu is a SCAM (don't order from the night menu if you want shredded chicken).  I want porridge and I don't want this.  And what does this freaking waiter say,  but you already ordered it so I have to charge you.  WTF YOU ARE CHARGING ME UNDER THE FALSE PRETENSE THAT I WOULD BE GETTING SHREDDED CHICKEN!!  ARGH!!

I was so pissed but I ate it since I was hungry.  I did not touch the damn chicken though because it was not shredded.  I was so pissed that sorry I had to leave no tip for crap service.  That is some half ass reason when your shredded chicken is different or not offered at all (and BTW this guy started talking about the lunch menu but how does that relate to this...).  I should have known going into an Asian restaurant.  No attempt of apologizing either.  Do these people know English.  Do they know the meaning of SHREDDED.  One bad experience is enough to  make me avoid this place, but kudos to you guys who enjoyed the food you ordered because it was what you ordered.  -______-
author: Yosie G.

description: Sadly, they discontinued the dish that I wanted to try, but overall, I liked it here. I liked their "Yin Yeung" (mixture of coffee and Hong Kong-style milk tea). I got their "homeless fried rice," which was pretty good. I made a checklist on their takeout menu before I came here to eat. I'm thinking about trying everything on that checklist, which means I going to have to come back.
author: Alex Y.

description: I used to come to T-28 almost every weekend for breakfast before I had my daughter, which was about 3 years ago.  After going to Tak Kee Lee for breakfast last weekend and found out that they've raised the prices - yes, I'm cheap when it comes to HK style breakfast, I've decided to come back to T-28 to see what their breakfast is like.  For $3.75 you get to pick either a porridge, noodle soup, or macaroni soup and it comes with your choice of milk tea, milk tea/coffee, coffee or soy milk.  For an additional .75 cents, you can add porridge, turnip cake, steamed rice rolls, or egg.  We ordered three breakfast specials w/ two additional sides and it came up to $14.70!  I thought that was such a great deal!
author: Katniss B.

description:
The best meal deals around the area hands down! The food is good, but their prices are even better! For about eight bucks, you get a huge bowl of imitation shark's fin soup, milk tea, a full-sized meal, and dessert. I like coming here for the shark's fin soup. Very well made and consistently tasty--a plus in my grade book. 

Their milk tea is above average--a little too much evaporated milk for my liking. It makes the milk tea a bit sour tasting, but it was OK. I ordered the spaghetti with the pork chop and chicken steak. The pork chop and chicken were fried perfectly. The tomato sauce is always too sweet for my liking so I never touch it and get it boxed. At home I remake the sauce by adding different shit to it, which further validates my own opinion that I should open up my own Hong Kong cafe. 

My sister's seafood spaghetti with pineapple and cream sauce was decent, though the pineapple in there is questionable. It doesn't make it delicious, so why even put it in the mix? The Portuguese Curried Mussels were OK, just baked mussels with yellow sauce on it. The mango pudding is awesome, though it tastes really processed. Still good, though. 

Final Verdict: If you happen to be in the area, then stop on by! The yummy shark's fin soup will make you cry. Their pasta is good but some things seem off. Don't pineapples and seafood belong in a pig's trough?
author: Florence W.

description: Mussels, mussels, mussels. Portugese-style, garlic, any-which-way. The gai-don hom-jue jook is hella good, too. Open late+good prices+ fresh seafood=you_gotta_eat_here_dot_com
author: Dan S.

description: The waitress and the guy that seated us was rude and acted like they were saving a table for someone but nobody ever sat at the reserved table. The place had some tables full but overall it was empty and stayed that way. What's the point of saying seat yourself when we try to sit at a table they tell us we can't sit there and sit at a specific table instead? So stupid...the food was average. I would rather go to D&A or ABC over this place. The prices at this place are more expensive and there's not too many specials. The clumsy waitress even drops one of our drink orders and acts pissed of at us because she has to go back and get another drink. Only reason we came here was because one of our family members wanted to try it out...a decision we regret.
author: Mike W.

description:
went there in a Friday late afternoon for tea time snack. 

yes, the price is cheaper, compared to the ones at East Bay (Fremont, Newark). The taste was so so. The milk tea. not good.  (Tak Kee is much better).

However, the service was good and attentive.
author: Hyman W.

description: Came here due to the Yelp review.  The food was disgusting and the only reason for a one star is because the waitress was really nice.  So disappointed.
author: Eva Y.

description: My star ratings for this place goes up after 9pm when you can get regular sized portions of food for about $3.50 per dish. The food is mediocre but the place is clean & cheap! This place reminds me of D & A Cafe with a smaller menu & better service
author: Jenny W.

description: I stumbled upon this place late one night. Fortunately for me, they have specials from 9pm - 11pm that are like 3 bucks. My late dinner ended up being quite cheap and plentiful. The food is decent - nothing too spectacular. I always try to hit up this place when I'm forced to have a late dinner.
author: Barney M.

description: Monday afternoon(6/10) I came here with a friend to eat. We order 2 iced lemon tea, baked curry beef over rice and some kind of fried rice. When we got our drinks my friend said hey isnt the color kind of off ? The color was murky like they put milk in it. So I asked her if she wants to exchange her drink because it was worst color than mine. ( she tasted it and it didnt taste what we order ) so she got her exchanged to a new one with no words from that waitress. Her drink is now clear and not murky so I decided to exchange mine as well. This time it was another waitress and I asked her, why is the color like this ? And I couldnt finish my other sentence because she started saying oh well you know it cant be milk because its lemon iced tea. And how sometimes lemon and sugar will turn into another color when mixed. Well do you want a new drink? It will still be the same color and wont make a difference So my friend showed her drink to her and she ignored it. In the end I got the drink exchanged and it still sisnt taste like it. It was sour.  I doubt ill be coming back here to eat.
author: Jessica T.

description:
So i had a pork chop! And it was SOO greasey! I didnt know i was at an auto body shop.... so unacceptable. When i cut the pork chop, it leaked grease. 

So good luck.
author: Tane S.

description: Terrible Terrible place. I sat here once for 45 minutes with no service. Note, this was at 6 or 7pm on a saturday, and I saw people who came in after us getting served. Tables were sticky, and the waiters were ignorant and didn't care. I actually spoke to a guy and he literally walked away from me when I asked about service. I will never go back to this establishment again.
author: Clinton L.

description: This place was actually pretty good. Different from your average chinese place, cause it's more of a cafe. Haven't been there since it's grand opening. Probably got worst. Cooks are probably lazy now. Bleh.
author: Katherine C.

description: Um why pay for food that I can make myself. Dinky menu.
author: Keit K.

description:
I wanted to give them zero stars because of their poor service and unprofessional demeanor, I gave one star because yelp makes you give at least one to post.
I recently ate at this cafe this past Saturday.  My first impression was that it seemed very clean and newly painted.  I was meeting my sister-in-law for a late lunch, I arrived shortly after her and when I went to place my order, the guy there told me that I couldn't sit with my own party and told me to sit at a table by myself.  Then after I agreed to this outrageous request, a waitress bumped into my baby's stroller while carrying a hot bowl of soup.  My sister-in-law asked the waitress to go around the other way and to not bump into our stroller again.  The entire wait staff refused to go around my stroller and continued to carry HOT food and liquids above my daughter's stroller and then had the nerve to complain about us blocking the walkway, where else was I supposed to put my daughter's stroller??? I had her right next to my table.  The people who worked there were very rude and unprofessional.  They insisted on bumping into my daughter's stroller (did I mention that my daughter is only 6 months old) and continued to be very rude to me and my sister-in-law each time they passed by.  I was so uncomfortable being at this cafe I couldn't even finish my food, which was very oily and had no taste, I asked for a take out box and the guy rolled his eyes at me and then just slammed an empty box on the counter and walked away.  Never in my life have I ever been treated with so much disrespect.  I do not recommend anyone going to eat at this cafe.  I read some of the other reviews and were surprised that I was treated so poorly.  
TO sum it up, I do not recommend to eat at this place unless you want very bad service, want to put your child at risk of a burn injury due to lack of common sense and tasteless greasy food.
author: Sheree A.

description: I've eaten here quite often due to my mom. She loves it and can't beat a bargain. Depending on the time of the day they have random specials. An example would be their 4-6pm Tea time specials. Nice little meals just to tide you over to dinner. There breakfast menu is classic HK style with rice porridge and other Macau style food. It's very clean and well lit. Usually its easy to find parking. I like taking my mom just because it makes her happy and is close. I'm not that keen on Asian food. But this place does blow away establishments such as ABC which is NASTY!
author: Mike W.

description: I only come here for the porridge/jook/congee in the morning!  It's decent and they give you big bowl w/ fried chinese donut, and a drink of your choice. All for under $4.  In terms of value, you can't beat that.
author: Crosby C.

description: So I am told by my Chinese friend that this place is actually named "The Little Flying Elephant" but you wouldn't know it unless you read Chinese. I think this is a far superior name to T-28 though the latter has a very Blade Runner-esque quality. This place is awesome for the quintessential hangover food or the late night drunk  dining experience. The white fish rice porridge is pretty damn good especially when you add the homemade chili garlic sauce found at each table. May I also suggest the dried beef chow fun, the ho fun is good and rarely made too oily. I usually order these two dishes and end up taking half of each home. Everything on the menu, especially the late night menu, is super cheap!!! My bill never exceeds $7 if I'm eating alone. I also enjoy their Hong Kong style iced coffee. The service is always friendly and FAST!!
author: eric m.

description:
It's all about the late night specials baby.  

Weeknights... between 9 and 12, they have really cheap late night specials.  when my pockets are hurting...  this is where i grab some macaroni soup and beef chow fun for about 10 bucks!!!  cheap eh?  

food is good price is cheap.  can't really beat that with the economy these days.
author: Don H.

description: This place gets extra points for being up the street from my house and having a late-night menu when I'm too lazy to cook.  The food is good.  I don't often venture into unknown food territory but I trust this place and have usually been pleasantly surprised.
author: Arthur K.

description: T28 is very similiar to the ABC Bakery cafes because of the Hong Style of food they offer. I usually order the daily specials with imitation shark fin soup (+.50 cent), drink, and dessert for about 7 dollars. The portions are big and the dishes are tasty. They have a variety of other dishes on their menu as well. I don't think any cost more than 6-7 dollars. Really good deal if you ask me.. especially now because we are in recession. Cash only!
author: Simon S.

description: This is a no frills type of place in the Sunset.  Their food is average but the jook (porridge) is excellent!  I've had jook in many places in the city and at T-28 it's consistent and creamy and not watery.  I've had their jook over 10+ and the quality is always the same.
author: Kenneth L.

description: yo this place is really really delicious go before 11:30am to get a mad deal it's ridiculous milk tea is really good porridge is good salted pork and 1000 year old egg is the one to get they keep it real you can watch the street cars go by if you're into street cars but you know i go here for food cause i'm usually hungry in the morning they are also open late so keep that in mind keep it trill99
author: Chin C.

description:
I really think Yelp should modify their rating system because there are just some establishments that just don't deserve even ONE star!!! I don't know what's up with all of the restaurants on Taraval but they ALL seem to be consistently just plain bad!!!! Perhaps they have a "terrible restaurants of Parkside Union" or something.  

The only thing I like about this place was that the setting of the establishment is consistently clean.  The second only thing I like was that their menu was very vast so you can pretty much order ALMOST anything; except ORDERING FOR WHAT YOUR MONEY'S WORTH!!!!!

I'm cook and I know cooking/running a restaurant is a tough business to run but there was NO EXCUSE for their poor services/poor food! I have been to PLENTY of Macao/HK style restaurants to know that there are plenty of restaurants out there that would put this establishment to shame! For example, if you order their "baked" plates, you expect to get your money's worth or at least be semi-filled even for your money, well not here.  Their baked beef w/tomato sauce and cheese on top was NO EXCUSE! The whole dish consisted about 90% rice and just a RIPE OFF stewed "GROUND BEEF---SHOULD NOT BE GROUND IN THE FIRST PLACE" in tomato sauce with just barely a sprinkle of cheese on top (not even melted and equivalent to a small packet of parmensan cheese you get when you buy a whole pizza).  Oh and here's the icing on top that makes this place the ultimate, "scam establishment", I would say for this dish, the only amount of nasty ground beef you got is equivalent to a TABLESPOON of meat.....So there you have it, NOT BAKED BEEF, IT'S BAKED RICE W/TOMATO SAUCE;NO VEGGIES TOO.

STAY FAR AWAY FROM THIS PLACE! IF YOU WANT A LATE NIGHT MEAL, BEST BET WOULD BE TO GO TO "ABC restaurant and bakery" on Irving and 32nd street than this dump.

Oh and here's what made my evening, the waiters did NOT CLEAR ANYTHING OFF OUR TABLES UNTIL WE LEFT!!!! Our table was so crowded with empty dishes (had to order several because of the ripe-off small portions here) we had a difficult time putting our left over "dishes of rice" in a container.  The staff just stood there, dumb founded! A friend and I had dinner at around 7pm and it wasn't even crowded (only one other table besides mine), so there was NO EXCUSE for them to just be standing around, looking in our direction knowing that we had a lot of EMPTY dishes around us and NOT PICKING THEM UP!!!!!

FOR ALL THE PEOPLE WHO GAVE THIS PLACE HIGH MARKS:

Do you even know what is "Food"? Do you even cook or are any of you Chefs???? Perhaps your lack of understanding of food and cooking is what's holding you back from giving an honest review (because you really don't know how to compare this place if you don't know how to cook or have never grown up in a cooking household).

As a chef, as a person who loves to see customers walk out of restaurants happy (because if you aren't cooking good food/providing good service then you aren't doing your job), and above all as a person willing to try ALL types of food be it game, strange, or foreign I URGE YOU FELLOW SAN FRANCISCANS, DO NOT COME HERE!!!!! THERE'S A REASON WHY SAN FRANCISCO HAS SOME OF THE BEST RESTAURANTS IN THE WORLD, EXPENSIVE OR CHEAP! THERE IS NO REASON WHY THIS PLACE SHOULD CONTINUE TO STAY IN BUSINESS, PLEASE DO NOT COME HERE, SO THAT IT CAN GO AWAY AND SOMETHING BETTER CAN REPLACE IT! 

Please, don't be lazy, just because it's open late, does not mean they deserve to stay in business! There are plenty of establishments that open late, like ABC restaurant (similar to T-28 and just better; not by much but you get your money's worth), just keep looking and don't stop over here!
author: NeverFoodFull F.

description: This place has really good fried tofu. Yay for spicey fried tofu! and good drinks. Haha. I love the title. Very smart name for the place. T-28; Taraval & 28th street! Yay!
author: Danielle Y.

description: southside southwest, gotta rename this section of the city, okay i will for now until someone does better, in honor of our brothers and sisters and bad driving, hk ... this smart cozy little hideaway for the hk style cafe is an oasis for hard studying asians, hk bangers, mom and dads for a quick bite; menu plans galore, so bring calculator and algebra textbook to get the best deal, also figure in when u go because that also determines the price ... oh the food, good decent, if  it is about the food, come and eat and dont trip!  out
author: tim y.

description: when i first went i thought hey the stuff isnt that bad. i mean its sortof like a chinese fusion with american food. after a few times. i was like ugh. i would say alot of my friends go there. they think its good. i mean for like 8 bucks you get big portions and drinks. ok.... i guess. its a decent place to go when your broke and you want something satisfying. but honestly you can go somewhere else. the food is just easy to make. then again i only order the specials they have for the weak. from what i heard they spit in your food.
author: Nicholas Y.

description: Just came here today . They have many menus so it took me a while to look through all of them and order LOL . T-28 is like another D&A but better .  They have late night special which and another special which is 3pm-6pm . They have a variety of food . They offer a lot of interesting things other cafes in SF don't offer . This place is very clean . They have a flat screen where they play chinese karaoke songs but you can barely hear them because the volume is turned down so low . The HK milk tea was way too bitter . Seems like they put too much tea and didn't put any condensed milk or sugar . The wonton noodle soup was ehh .. mediocre . The wonton didn't look like wonton at all .. they were very big and tasted like sui-mai . The noodles that came with the wonton got tiring . The macau style pork chop bun was suprisingly good .The jook was very good too . It was too liquidy like the jook you get at ABC but it wasn't too thick either . It was just right and full of flavor . The porportion was just right . I love their hot sauce !! It's not the cheap hot sauce other restaurants and cafes use . The hot sauce is very flavorful . Dirty cheap prices for good food ! Two wonton noodle soups , a jook , a macau style pork chop bun , a jelly hk milk tea , and a ice cream float came out to be only $20 !! If you're thinking of going to ABC , consider this as an alternative .. cheaper , cleaner , and better food !!
author: Eileen L.

description: It opens pretty late. I like ordering the pork bun. The congee is okay. The prices are cheap. I don't recall ever ordering a drink.
author: bob k.

description: I love their beef chow fun.  It's really cheap from 3-5 and after 9 p.m.  The bosses there are very friendly and you can tell that it's family owned and run.  I especially appreciate these establishments.  You must also try their fake shark fin soup.  Their portions are generous and filling.
author: Gina R.
